   56M with asthma, DM, HTN presenting with respiratory distress and
   pneumonia/ARDS from influenza A
   .
   # Respiratory failure:  Cause of respiratory failure most likely
   ARDS/sepsis combined w/ fluid overload and possible bacterial
   pneumonia. p/F<200 initially, today is improving and outside of ARDS
   range and patient is breathing well off of paralysis. His improvement
   seems to be mostly due to very good diuresis.  Thoracic surgery
   consulted and are willing to do trach placement once PEEP is 8 or
   lower. PEEP now 8. thoracic surgery aware, patient planned for OR
   Monday unless off ventilator by then.  Tolerating pressure support
   well. Patient became agitated off sedation, will need to wean sedation
   slowly as this is likely the major barrier to extubation.
   - Try to wean pressure support back to 8 so that can get trach on
   Monday; ENT will leave pre-op surgery recs in chart tomorrow.
   - Daily CXR
   -Will continue diuresis , check evening lytes and give acetazolamide if
   needed
   .
   #Fevers/leukocytosis: Patient with low-grade fevers overnight, WBC
   count trending up. Currently on broad spectrum antibiotics. Not
   covering for VRE, yeast. Concern for possible yeast line infection vs.
   C diff. Line site looks good making concern for this slightly lower;
   blood cultures negative to date.
   - will d/c lines if culture positive, however given that patient has
   acute need for lines will culture prior to line d/c
   - consider starting fluconazole or VRE coverage
   .
   # Pneumonia: Patient has severe influenza with ARDS and possible
   bacterial superinfection.  He has completed his courses of antibiotics,
   and cultures have been negative besides influenza virus.  However,
   given the severity of his illness we will continue broad spectrum
   antibiotics for a total 14 day course. Finished azithromycin yesterday.
   -Continue Vanco (day 13/14), aztreonam for (day13/14) day total course
   for GN coverage
   - Continue peramivir for total 10 days as patient not improving (done
   [**12-20**])
   - While on peramivir will need daily ECG and skin checks to monitor for
   toxicity.
   - f/u ID recs.
   .
   #Renal failure: Urine output and creatinine have improved.  Has muddy
   casts on urine sediment per renal, seems to have component of ATN.
   - renal team has signed off
   - Lasix gtt.  Goal as negative as possible given that patient is
   relatively euvolemic, may not be able to be diuresed much more.
   - [**Hospital1 **] lytes while being diuresed.
   - With improving renal function and normal phosphate, will consider
   stopping calcium acetate.
   .
   # Eye redness and discharge: Per nursing, patient had contact in his
   right eye which was only removed the other day as there was no record
   that patient wore contacts. Unable to find contact in left eye.  Seen
   by ophthalmology who mentioned that contact was intentionally there.
   Also suggested some changes to his eye-drops and outpatient follow-up.
   Patient already has outpatient appointment set up
   - Prednisolone and tobramycin drops to R eye as prescribed.
   - Artificial tears ointment to both eyes
   .
   #Tachycardia: Likely multifocal atrial tachycardia. Patient started on
   Lopressor 12.5 mg PO BID. Will not increase as patient tolerates lasix
   drip better when blood pressure slightly increased. If patient is
   tachycardic or hypertensive later in the day with decreased sedation,
   will increase this as needed.
   -Lopressor 12.5 mg PO BID
   .
   # Rash: Rash seems to be improving now that zosyn d/c
d.  No signs of
   DRESS.  Has some signs of folliculitis today
   - Chlorhexadine wash on arms and legs to help prevent infection of
   follicles
   - Continue to monitor.
   .
   #Abdominal distension: Seems to have poor motility with paralysis that
   leads to increasing bowel distention.  Will continue gentle tube feeds.
   Patient has had some loose stools today, checked C. diff to ensure that
   he is not infected given that he is on a large number of antibiotics
   and was  negative X3.  Rectal tube placed which seems to be improving
   his distention
   - Bowel regimen.
   -continue rectal tubes
   .
   # R hand swelling
   - U/S of R arm
    .
   # Hypothyroidism: Per most recent d/c summary, Synthroid at 50mcg daily
   or 25 IV.  Continued here.
   .
   #DM II: Blood glucose has been low on insulin drip, high on insulin
   sliding scale
   - d/c Insulin drip and re-write for more aggressive sliding scale.
   .
   #GERD: PPI
   FEN: No IVF, replete electrolytes PRN, renal tube feeds.
   Prophylaxis: Subutaneous heparin; pneumoboots, PPI and bowel regimen
   Access: peripherals, Aline, IJ Central line
   Code:  Full Code as discussed with parents.
   Communication: Father and mother
   Disposition: pending improved respiratory status.

Summary:

The patient is a 56-year-old male with a chief complaint of ARDS, who is currently intubated and receiving mechanical ventilation. He has a history of asthma, DM, and HTN. He was admitted with respiratory distress and pneumonia/ARDS from influenza A. His respiratory status has improved, and he is now tolerating pressure support well. However, he remains on broad-spectrum antibiotics and has a high risk of yeast line infection.

The patient's laboratory results show:

* WBC count trending up
* Low-grade fevers overnight
* Blood cultures negative to date
* Yeast in sputum
* Commensal respiratory flora absent
* CDiff negative x3

The patient's vital signs are:

* T: 37.8°C (100.1°F)
* HR: 99 bpm
* BP: 117/68 mmHg
* RR: 20 inspirations per minute
* SpO2: 96%
* CVP: 15 mmHg

The patient's physical examination shows:

* Sedated and intubated
* Decreased BS at bases
* Mildly distended abdomen
* Trace edema in LE
* R hand 2+ edema (no erythema)

Potential medical complications:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's ARDS may worsen, leading to respiratory failure.
2. Sepsis: The patient's high risk of yeast line infection and low-grade fevers overnight increase the risk of sepsis.
3. Renal failure: The patient's urine output and creatinine have improved, but he still has muddy casts on urine sediment, indicating a component of ATN.
4. Pneumonia: The patient's severe influenza with ARDS and possible bacterial superinfection may lead to pneumonia.
5. Tachycardia: The patient's multifocal atrial tachycardia may worsen, leading to cardiac complications.
6. Rash: The patient's folliculitis may worsen, leading to skin complications.
7. Abdominal distension: The patient's poor motility with paralysis may lead to increasing bowel distention.
8. R hand swelling: The patient's R hand swelling may indicate a deeper underlying issue.

Assessment and plan:

The patient's respiratory status has improved, but he remains at high risk for respiratory failure and sepsis. The patient's renal function is improving, but he still has a component of ATN. The patient's tachycardia is likely multifocal atrial tachycardia, and his rash is improving. The patient's abdominal distension is improving, but he still has poor motility. The patient's R hand swelling is a concern and requires further evaluation.

The plan is to:

* Continue broad-spectrum antibiotics for a total 14-day course
* Monitor the patient's respiratory status and adjust ventilation as needed
* Continue diuresis and check evening lytes
* Consider starting fluconazole or VRE coverage
* Continue peramivir for total 10 days
* Monitor the patient's renal function and adjust treatment as needed
* Continue to monitor the patient's tachycardia and adjust treatment as needed
* Continue to monitor the patient's rash and adjust treatment as needed
* Continue to monitor the patient's abdominal distension and adjust treatment as needed
* Continue to monitor the patient's R hand swelling and adjust treatment as needed.

   - Artificial tears ointment to both eyes
   .

   Lopressor 12.5 mg PO BID. Will not increase as patient tolerates lasix
   drip better when blood pressure slightly increased. If patient is
   tachycardic or hypertensive later in the day with decreased sedation,
   will increase this as needed.
   -Lopressor 12.5 mg PO BID
   .

d.  No signs of
   DRESS.  Has some signs of folliculitis today
   - Chlorhexadine wash on arms and legs to help prevent infection of

   - Continue to monitor.
   .

   he is not infected given that he is on a large number of antibiotics

   his distention

   .

Based on the provided progress note, I summarize the patient's current condition as follows:

* The patient is a 56-year-old male with a history of asthma, diabetes, and hypertension who presented with respiratory distress and pneumonia/ARDS due to influenza A.
* The patient's respiratory status is improving, with a p/F ratio outside the ARDS range, and he is breathing well off of paralysis.
* The patient has been on broad-spectrum antibiotics, which have been negative, and there is concern for possible yeast line infection or C. diff.
* The patient has completed his courses of antibiotics and will continue on a 14-day course of vancomycin and aztreonam for Gram-negative coverage.
* The patient has severe influenza with ARDS and possible bacterial superinfection, and will continue on peramivir for a total of 10 days.
* The patient's renal function is improving, with muddy casts on urine sediment suggesting a component of acute tubular necrosis (ATN).
* The patient has been on diuresis and will continue to be monitored for electrolyte imbalances.
* The patient has a tachycardia, likely multifocal atrial tachycardia, and has been started on Lopressor 12.5 mg PO BID.
* The patient has a rash, which seems to be improving, and will continue to be monitored.
* The patient has abdominal distension due to poor motility and will continue on gentle tube feeds.
* The patient has a rectal tube in place to help manage his distension.

Potential medical complications that may arise include:

* Respiratory failure due to ongoing pneumonia or ARDS
* Sepsis or septic shock due to bacterial superinfection or line infection
* Renal failure or further deterioration of renal function
* Cardiac complications, such as arrhythmias or heart failure, due to tachycardia or hypertension
* Gastrointestinal complications, such as bowel obstruction or perforation, due to poor motility or distension
* Infection or sepsis due to contact lenses or eye drops
* Thyroid complications, such as hypothyroidism, due to Synthroid therapy
* Diabetic ketoacidosis or hyperglycemic hyperosmolar syndrome due to insulin therapy
* Gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD) or other gastrointestinal complications due to PPI therapy.

 HYPERGLYCEMIA
 ACUTE RESPIRATORY DISTRESS SYNDROME (ARDS, ACUTE LUNG INJURY, [**Doctor Last Name 76**])

 AIRWAY, INABILITY TO PROTECT (RISK FOR ASPIRATION, ALTERED GAG,
   AIRWAY CLEARANCE, COUGH)
   56M with asthma, DM, HTN presenting with respiratory distress and
   pneumonia/ARDS from influenza A/H1N1.
   Active issues:
   # Respiratory failure: ARDS/sepsis combined w/ fluid overload and
   possible bacterial pneumonia.  Thoracic surgery consulted and are
   willing to do trach placement once PEEP is 8 or lower. Patient planned
   for OR Monday unless off ventilator by then.
   - Will try on PS today to see if we can wean him down and avoid a trach
   - If unable, TF
s stopped after midnight
   #Fevers/leukocytosis: Patient with low-grade fevers overnight, WBC
   count trending up. Currently on broad spectrum antibiotics and we have
   no recent infxns for which we are treating. Has completed courses of
   Azithro, Peramivir, and continuing Vanc/Aztreo had been discussed.
   However, he has received full courses of these ABx and it seems
   reasonable to see how he does off of these now.
   - D/C all ABx today but with lower threshold to restart if continues to
   be febrile or worsens
   - Keeping in lines for now as he needs them, but would consider pulling
   if worsens
   # Pneumonia: Patient has severe influenza with ARDS and possible
   bacterial superinfection.  He has completed his courses of antibiotics,
   and cultures have been negative besides influenza virus.  As above for
   ABx regimen
 has now completed Peramivir course, Azithro, and will d/c
   Vanc/Aztreonam today.
   #Renal failure: Urine output and creatinine have improved.  Has muddy
   casts on urine sediment per renal, seems to have component of ATN.
   - Already negative this morning so will hold Lasix gtt and see how he
   does through the day
   - Goal will be even for the day
   - Renal team has signed off
   # DM2: Was on insulin gtt until recently, but now switched to Glargine
   40U qhs and SSI. Has increasing SSI needs. Will need to calculate
   insulin requirements through today and increase Glargine, however,
   should probably do this after his TF
s have been restarted (holding
   tonight after midnight for possible trach tomorrow).
   Other stable issues:
   # Eye redness and discharge: Per nursing, patient had contact in his
   right eye which was only removed the other day as there was no record
   that patient wore contacts. Unable to find contact in left eye.  Seen
   by ophthalmology who mentioned that contact was intentionally there.
   Also suggested some changes to his eye-drops and outpatient follow-up.
   Patient already has outpatient appointment set up
   - Prednisolone and tobramycin drops to R eye as prescribed.
   - Artificial tears ointment to both eyes
   #Tachycardia: Likely multifocal atrial tachycardia. Patient started on
   Lopressor 12.5 mg PO BID. Will not increase as patient tolerates lasix
   drip better when blood pressure slightly increased. If patient is
   tachycardic or hypertensive later in the day with decreased sedation,
   will increase this as needed.
   -Lopressor 12.5 mg PO BID
   # Rash: Rash seems to be improving now that zosyn d/c
d.  No signs of
   DRESS.  Has some signs of folliculitis today
   - Chlorhexadine wash on arms and legs to help prevent infection of
   follicles
   - Continue to monitor.
   #Abdominal distension: Seems to have poor motility with paralysis that
   leads to increasing bowel distention.  Will continue gentle tube feeds.
   Patient has had some loose stools today, checked C. diff to ensure that
   he is not infected given that he is on a large number of antibiotics
   and was  negative X3.  Rectal tube placed which seems to be improving
   his distention
   - Bowel regimen.
   -continue rectal tubes
   # R hand swelling
   - U/S of R arm
   # Hypothyroidism: Per most recent d/c summary, Synthroid at 50mcg daily
   or 25 IV.  Continued here.
   #GERD: PPI
   FEN: No IVF, replete electrolytes PRN, renal tube feeds.
   Prophylaxis: Subutaneous heparin; pneumoboots, PPI and bowel regimen
   Access: peripherals, Aline, IJ Central line
   Code:  Full Code as discussed with parents.
   Communication: Father and mother
   Disposition: pending improved respiratory status.

Based on the progress note, the patient is a 56-year-old male with a history of asthma, diabetes, and hypertension, who presented with respiratory distress and pneumonia/ARDS from influenza A/H1N1. The patient's current status is as follows:

* Respiratory support: The patient is on mechanical ventilation with a PEEP of 10 cmH2O, FiO2 of 50%, and a VT of 280 mL. The patient is unable to wean from the ventilator and has a RSBI of 0.
* Hemodynamics: The patient's blood pressure is 87/71 mmHg, and his heart rate is 99 bpm.
* Renal function: The patient has acute renal failure, with a creatinine of 1.2 mg/dL and a urine output of 2,317 mL.
* Electrolytes: The patient's potassium level is 4.2 mEq/L, and his magnesium level is 1.8 mg/dL.
* Infection: The patient has been treated with broad-spectrum antibiotics, including azithromycin, peramavir, and vancomycin, but cultures have been negative. The patient has completed courses of antibiotics and is currently off of them.
* Other issues: The patient has a rash, which is improving, and has some signs of folliculitis. The patient has also had some loose stools and has been treated with bowel regimen.

The patient's medical complications include:

* Acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS)
* Sepsis without organ dysfunction
* Pneumonia
* Acute renal failure
* Hyperglycemia
* Constipation
* Tachycardia
* Hypothyroidism
* GERD

The patient's current treatment plan includes:

* Mechanical ventilation with a PEEP of 10 cmH2O and FiO2 of 50%
* Broad-spectrum antibiotics
* Vancomycin and aztreonam have been discontinued
* Lopressor 12.5 mg PO BID for tachycardia
* Prednisolone and tobramycin drops to the right eye for eye redness and discharge
* Artificial tears ointment to both eyes
* Chlorhexadine wash on arms and legs to help prevent infection of follicles
* Gentle tube feeds
* Rectal tubes to improve bowel distension
* Synthroid at 50mcg daily or 25 IV for hypothyroidism
* PPI for GERD
* Prophylaxis with subcutaneous heparin, pneumoboots, and bowel regimen

The patient's potential medical complications include:

* Respiratory failure
* Sepsis with organ dysfunction
* Pneumonia
* Acute renal failure
* Hyperglycemia
* Constipation
* Tachycardia
* Hypothyroidism
* GERD
* DVT
* Pneumonia
* ARDS
* Sepsis

Summary:

The patient is a 56-year-old male with a history of asthma, diabetes, and hypertension, who presented with respiratory distress and pneumonia/ARDS from influenza A. He is currently intubated and receiving mechanical ventilation. His respiratory status has improved, and he is tolerating pressure support well. However, he remains at risk for respiratory failure due to ARDS/sepsis, fluid overload, and possible bacterial pneumonia.

The patient has several medical complications, including:

1. Tachycardia: likely multifocal atrial tachycardia, being treated with Lopressor 12.5 mg PO BID.
2. Rash: improving, but still present, with signs of folliculitis, being treated with chlorhexadine wash and monitored.
3. Renal failure: acute renal failure, with muddy casts on urine sediment, being treated with Lasix gtt and diuresis.
4. Hyperglycemia: being managed with insulin drip and sliding scale.
5. Constipation: being treated with bowel regimen and rectal tubes.
6. Eye redness and discharge: being treated with prednisolone and tobramycin drops to the right eye, and artificial tears ointment to both eyes.
7. Abdominal distension: being treated with gentle tube feeds and rectal tubes.

Potential medical complications that may arise include:

1. Respiratory failure: due to ARDS/sepsis, fluid overload, and possible bacterial pneumonia.
2. Sepsis: due to the patient's immunocompromised state and ongoing bacterial infection.
3. Line infection: due to the patient's need for multiple lines and the risk of line-related complications.
4. Kidney injury: due to the patient's acute renal failure and potential for further kidney damage.
5. Eye complications: due to the patient's eye redness and discharge, and the risk of further complications if not properly treated.
6. Gastrointestinal complications: due to the patient's constipation and abdominal distension, and the risk of further complications if not properly managed.

The patient's plan of care includes:

1. Continued mechanical ventilation and pressure support.
2. Ongoing diuresis and fluid management.
3. Aggressive antibiotic therapy to cover for possible bacterial infection.
4. Monitoring of the patient's respiratory status and adjusting therapy as needed.
5. Continued management of the patient's medical complications, including tachycardia, rash, renal failure, hyperglycemia, constipation, and eye redness and discharge.
6. Planning for tracheostomy and extubation, pending improvement in the patient's respiratory status.

   pneumonia/ARDS from influenza A/H1N1.
   Active issues:
   # Respiratory failure: ARDS/sepsis combined w/ fluid overload and
   possible bacterial pneumonia.  Thoracic surgery consulted and are
   willing to do trach placement once PEEP is 8 or lower. Patient planned
   for OR Monday unless off ventilator by then.
   - Will try on PS today to see if we can wean him down and avoid a trach
   - If unable, TF
s stopped after midnight
   #Fevers/leukocytosis: Patient with low-grade fevers overnight, WBC
   count trending up. Currently on broad spectrum antibiotics and we have
   no recent infxns for which we are treating. Has completed courses of
   Azithro, Peramivir, and continuing Vanc/Aztreo had been discussed.
   However, he has received full courses of these ABx and it seems
   reasonable to see how he does off of these now.
   - D/C all ABx today but with lower threshold to restart if continues to
   be febrile or worsens
   - Keeping in lines for now as he needs them, but would consider pulling
   if worsens
   # Pneumonia: Patient has severe influenza with ARDS and possible
   bacterial superinfection.  He has completed his courses of antibiotics,
   and cultures have been negative besides influenza virus.  As above for
   ABx regimen
 has now completed Peramivir course, Azithro, and will d/c
   Vanc/Aztreonam today.
   #Renal failure: Urine output and creatinine have improved.  Has muddy
   casts on urine sediment per renal, seems to have component of ATN.
   - Already negative this morning so will hold Lasix gtt and see how he
   does through the day
   - Goal will be even for the day
   - Renal team has signed off
   # DM2: Was on insulin gtt until recently, but now switched to Glargine
   40U qhs and SSI. Has increasing SSI needs. Will need to calculate
   insulin requirements through today and increase Glargine, however,
   should probably do this after his TF
s have been restarted (holding
   tonight after midnight for possible trach tomorrow).
   Other stable issues:
   # Eye redness and discharge: Per nursing, patient had contact in his
   right eye which was only removed the other day as there was no record
   that patient wore contacts. Unable to find contact in left eye.  Seen
   by ophthalmology who mentioned that contact was intentionally there.
   Also suggested some changes to his eye-drops and outpatient follow-up.
   Patient already has outpatient appointment set up
   - Prednisolone and tobramycin drops to R eye as prescribed.
   - Artificial tears ointment to both eyes
   #Tachycardia: Likely multifocal atrial tachycardia. Patient started on
   Lopressor 12.5 mg PO BID. Will not increase as patient tolerates lasix
   drip better when blood pressure slightly increased. If patient is
   tachycardic or hypertensive later in the day with decreased sedation,
   will increase this as needed.
   -Lopressor 12.5 mg PO BID
   # Rash: Rash seems to be improving now that zosyn d/c
d.  No signs of
   DRESS.  Has some signs of folliculitis today
   - Chlorhexadine wash on arms and legs to help prevent infection of
   follicles
   - Continue to monitor.
   #Abdominal distension: Seems to have poor motility with paralysis that
   leads to increasing bowel distention.  Will continue gentle tube feeds.
   Patient has had some loose stools today, checked C. diff to ensure that
   he is not infected given that he is on a large number of antibiotics
   and was  negative X3.  Rectal tube placed which seems to be improving
   his distention
   - Bowel regimen.
   -continue rectal tubes
   # R hand swelling
   - U/S of R arm
   # Hypothyroidism: Per most recent d/c summary, Synthroid at 50mcg daily
   or 25 IV.  Continued here.
   #GERD: PPI
   FEN: No IVF, replete electrolytes PRN, renal tube feeds.
   Prophylaxis: Subutaneous heparin; pneumoboots, PPI and bowel regimen
   Access: peripherals, Aline, IJ Central line
   Code:  Full Code as discussed with parents.
   Communication: Father and mother who are in to see him daily
   Disposition: pending improved respiratory status.

Based on the provided progress note, I summarize the patient's current condition and potential medical complications as follows:

**Current Condition:**

* The patient is a 56-year-old male with a history of asthma, diabetes mellitus (DM), and hypertension (HTN) who is currently intubated and ventilated due to acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS) and pneumonia/ARDS from influenza A/H1N1.
* He has a fever (101.1°F), tachycardia, and hypertension, and is receiving broad-spectrum antibiotics.
* His respiratory support includes CPAP/PSV with a PEEP of 5 cmH2O and FiO2 of 50%.
* He has a mild abdominal distension and constipation, and is receiving gentle tube feeds.
* His renal function is improving, but he has acute renal failure (ARF) with muddy casts on urine sediment, suggesting a component of acute tubular necrosis (ATN).
* He has a rash on his bilateral arms, which appears to be improving, and has signs of folliculitis.

**Potential Medical Complications:**

* Respiratory failure: The patient's ARDS and pneumonia/ARDS may worsen, leading to further respiratory failure.
* Sepsis: The patient's fever and tachycardia may indicate ongoing sepsis, which could lead to organ dysfunction.
* Renal failure: The patient's ARF may progress, leading to further decline in renal function.
* Constipation: The patient's constipation may worsen, leading to bowel obstruction or perforation.
* Pneumonia: The patient's pneumonia may worsen, leading to further respiratory failure or sepsis.
* Hyperglycemia: The patient's DM may worsen, leading to hyperglycemia and potential complications such as ketoacidosis or hyperosmolar nonketotic coma.
* Airway compromise: The patient's intubation and ventilator dependence may lead to airway compromise or aspiration.
* Tracheostomy: The patient's respiratory failure may require a tracheostomy, which carries risks such as bleeding, infection, and airway compromise.
* Infection: The patient's multiple antibiotic courses and presence of central lines and tubes may increase his risk of infection, including central line-associated bloodstream infection (CLABSI) and ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP).
* Hyperthyroidism: The patient's hypothyroidism may worsen, leading to hyperthyroidism and potential complications such as atrial fibrillation or thyroid storm.
* Gastrointestinal bleeding: The patient's constipation and abdominal distension may increase his risk of gastrointestinal bleeding.

**Assessment and Plan:**

* The patient's respiratory failure and pneumonia/ARDS will be closely monitored, and he will be weaned off ventilator support as tolerated.
* His antibiotics will be discontinued, and he will be closely monitored for signs of infection or sepsis.
* His renal function will be closely monitored, and he will receive supportive care for his ARF.
* His constipation will be managed with gentle tube feeds and bowel regimen.
* His hyperglycemia will be managed with insulin therapy.
* His airway compromise will be closely monitored, and he will be considered for tracheostomy if necessary.
* His infection risk will be minimized by maintaining proper infection control practices and monitoring for signs of infection.
* His hyperthyroidism will be monitored, and thyroid hormone replacement therapy will be adjusted as necessary.
* His gastrointestinal bleeding risk will be monitored, and he will receive supportive care for any bleeding complications.

Based on the provided progress note, I summarize the patient's health status as follows:

The patient is a 56-year-old male with a history of asthma, diabetes, and hypertension, who presented with respiratory distress and pneumonia/ARDS due to influenza A/H1N1. He has been admitted to the ICU and is currently intubated and ventilated.

The patient's current vital signs are:

* Temperature: 101.1°F (38.4°C)
* Heart rate: 93 bpm
* Blood pressure: 121/70 mmHg
* Respiratory rate: 22 breaths per minute
* Oxygen saturation: 96%
* SpO2: 96%

The patient has several active issues, including:

1. Respiratory failure: ARDS/sepsis combined with fluid overload and possible bacterial pneumonia.
2. Fevers/leukocytosis: The patient has been febrile to 101.1°F (38.4°C) with a rising white blood cell count.
3. Pneumonia: The patient has severe influenza with ARDS and possible bacterial superinfection.
4. Renal failure: The patient has acute kidney injury with muddy casts on urine sediment, suggesting a component of acute tubular necrosis.
5. Diabetes: The patient has type 2 diabetes and is currently on insulin glargine 40U qhs and sliding scale insulin.

The patient's laboratory results show:

* White blood cell count: 13.2 K/uL
* Hemoglobin: 8.8 g/dL
* Platelet count: 65 mg/dL
* Blood urea nitrogen: 37 mg/dL
* Creatinine: 1.1 mg/dL
* Glucose: 132 mg/dL
* Albumin: 2.3 g/dL
* Calcium: 8.9 mg/dL
* Magnesium: 1.8 mg/dL
* Phosphate: 5.0 mg/dL

The patient's radiology results show:

* Chest X-ray: Slight worsening from previous X-ray, overall trend much improved.

The patient's medical complications include:

* Respiratory failure
* Sepsis
* ARDS
* Pneumonia
* Renal failure
* Acute kidney injury
* Diabetes
* Hyperglycemia
* Constipation
* Hypothyroidism
* GERD

The patient's plan includes:

* Continuing broad-spectrum antibiotics for 48 hours
* Monitoring for signs of sepsis and adjusting antibiotic regimen as necessary
* Considering tracheostomy and percutaneous endoscopic gastrostomy (PEG) if unable to extubate
* Continuing gentle tube feeds and monitoring for signs of bowel obstruction
* Managing hypertension with Lopressor 12.5 mg PO BID
* Monitoring for signs of rash and adjusting treatment as necessary
* Continuing prophylactic heparin and PPI

Based on this information, potential medical complications that may arise include:

* Continued respiratory failure and ARDS
* Development of bacterial superinfection
* Worsening of renal failure and acute kidney injury
* Hyperglycemia and diabetic ketoacidosis
* Constipation and bowel obstruction
* Hypothyroidism and hypocalcemia
* GERD and aspiration pneumonia

It is essential to closely monitor the patient's condition and adjust treatment as necessary to prevent these complications and improve his overall health status.

   56M with asthma, DM, HTN presenting with respiratory distress and
   pneumonia/ARDS from influenza A/H1N1.
   Active issues:
   # Respiratory failure: Originially ARDS/sepsis combined w/ fluid
   overload and possible bacterial pneumonia.  Patient planned to go today
   with thoracic surgery for trach and PEG.
   - Trach and PEG by interventional pulmonology this morning.
   - TF
s stopped after midnight
   #Fevers/leukocytosis: Febrile to 101.1 last night, pan-cultured, but no
   clear source.  Currently off of antibiotics, and given lack of source
   we will not start any medications at this time. Has completed courses
   of Azithro, Peramivir, and continuing Vanc/Aztreo had been discussed.
   However, he has received full courses of these ABx and it seems
   reasonable to see how he does off of these now.
   - D/C all ABx yesterday but with lower threshold to restart if
   continues to be febrile or worsens
   - Keeping in right IJ for now as he needs them, but would consider
   pulling if worsens
   # Pneumonia: Patient has severe influenza with ARDS and possible
   bacterial superinfection.  He has completed his courses of antibiotics,
   and cultures have been negative besides influenza virus.  Stopped
   antibiotics yesterday.
   #Renal failure: Urine output and creatinine have improved.  Has muddy
   casts on urine sediment per renal, seems to have component of ATN.
   - Off of lasix gtt
   - Goal will be even for the day
   - Renal team has signed off
   # DM2: Was on insulin gtt until recently, but now switched to Glargine
   40U qhs and SSI. Has increasing SSI needs. Will need to calculate
   insulin requirements through today and increase Glargine, however,
   should probably do this after his TF
s have been restarted (holding
   tonight after midnight for possible trach today).
   Other stable issues:
   # Eye redness and discharge: Per nursing, patient had contact in his
   right eye which was only removed the other day as there was no record
   that patient wore contacts. Unable to find contact in left eye.  Seen
   by ophthalmology who mentioned that contact was intentionally there.
   Also suggested some changes to his eye-drops and outpatient follow-up.
   Patient already has outpatient appointment set up
   - Prednisolone and tobramycin drops to R eye as prescribed.
   - Artificial tears ointment to both eyes
   #Tachycardia: Likely multifocal atrial tachycardia. Patient started on
   Lopressor 12.5 mg PO BID. Will not increase as patient tolerates lasix
   drip better when blood pressure slightly increased. If patient is
   tachycardic or hypertensive later in the day with decreased sedation,
   will increase this as needed.
   -Lopressor 12.5 mg PO BID
   # Rash: Rash seems to be improving now that zosyn d/c
d.  No signs of
   DRESS.  Has some signs of folliculitis today
   - Chlorhexadine wash on arms and legs to help prevent infection of
   follicles
   - Continue to monitor.
   #Abdominal distension: Seems to have poor motility with paralysis that
   leads to increasing bowel distention.  Will continue gentle tube feeds.
   Patient has had some loose stools today, checked C. diff to ensure that
   he is not infected given that he is on a large number of antibiotics
   and was  negative X3.  Rectal tube placed which seems to be improving
   his distention
   - Bowel regimen.
   -continue rectal tubes
   # R hand swelling
   - U/S of R arm
   # Hypothyroidism: Per most recent d/c summary, Synthroid at 50mcg daily
   or 25 IV.  Continued here.
   #GERD: PPI
   FEN: No IVF, replete electrolytes PRN, renal tube feeds.
   Prophylaxis: Subutaneous heparin; pneumoboots, PPI and bowel regimen
   Access: peripherals, Aline, IJ Central line
   Code:  Full Code as discussed with parents.
   Communication: Father and mother who are in to see him daily
   Disposition: pending improved respiratory status.<|eot_id|><|start_header_id|>assistant<|end_header_id|>

10. Rash: The patient's rash is improving, but there is a risk of further skin reactions, particularly with the use of antibiotics.

To mitigate these potential complications, the patient should be closely monitored for any signs of deterioration, and the medical team should be prepared to adjust the treatment plan as needed.

   56M with asthma, DM, HTN presenting with respiratory distress and
   pneumonia/ARDS from influenza A/H1N1.
   Active issues:
   # Respiratory failure: Originially ARDS/sepsis combined w/ fluid
   overload and possible bacterial pneumonia.  Pt has now been trach'ed
   but didn't get PEG due to problems with EGD scope, so planning to go
   today. Continues now on CPAP 10/5, 50%.
   - Tomorrow consider trach mask trials, but will defer for now until
   after PEG placed
   - To get PEG today
   #Fevers/leukocytosis: Febrile to 101.1 two nights ago, pan-cultured,
   but no clear source and Cx's continue to be negative. Budding yeast in
   most recent sputum likely OP flora.  Currently off of antibiotics, and
   given lack of source we will not start any medications at this time.
   Has completed courses of Azithro, Peramivir, and continuing Vanc/Aztreo
   had been discussed. However, he has received full courses of these ABx
   and it seems reasonable to see how he does off of these now.
   - D/C all ABx yesterday but with lower threshold to restart if
   continues to be febrile or worsens
   - Would more strongly pulling R IJ and if continues to have IV needs,
   consider a PICC
   # Acute drop in Hct: Did have a minor surgery yesterday but wouldn't
   think pt would lose a whole unit of blood.
   - Repeat Hct later this evening and continues to go down will transfuse
   # Pneumonia: Patient has severe influenza with ARDS and possible
   bacterial superinfection.  He has completed his courses of antibiotics,
   and cultures have been negative besides influenza virus.  Stopped
   antibiotics yesterday.
    #Renal failure: Urine output and creatinine have improved.  Has muddy
   casts on urine sediment per renal, seems to have component of ATN.
   - Off of lasix gtt
   - Goal will be even for the day
   - Renal team has signed off
   # DM2: Was on insulin gtt until recently, but now switched to Glargine
   40U qhs and SSI. Has increasing SSI needs.
   - Will calculate insulin requirements once pt is taking PO. Not today,
   as pt currently NPO for PEG today
   # Critical illness myopathy:
    - Need to address underlying illness and once pt wakes up a little
   more, will consult PT
   [**Name (NI) **] stable issues:
   # Eye redness and discharge: Per nursing, patient had contact in his
   right eye which was only removed the other day as there was no record
   that patient wore contacts. Unable to find contact in left eye.  Seen
   by ophthalmology who mentioned that contact was intentionally there.
   Also suggested some changes to his eye-drops and outpatient follow-up.
   Patient already has outpatient appointment set up
   - Prednisolone and tobramycin drops to R eye as prescribed.
   - Artificial tears ointment to both eyes
   #Tachycardia: Likely multifocal atrial tachycardia. Patient started on
   Lopressor 12.5 mg PO BID. Will not increase as patient tolerates lasix
   drip better when blood pressure slightly increased. If patient is
   tachycardic or hypertensive later in the day with decreased sedation,
   will increase this as needed.
   -Lopressor 12.5 mg PO BID
   # Rash: Rash seems to be improving now that zosyn d/c
d.  No signs of
   DRESS.  Has some signs of folliculitis today
   - Chlorhexadine wash on arms and legs to help prevent infection of
   follicles
   - Continue to monitor.
   #Abdominal distension: Seems to have poor motility with paralysis that
   leads to increasing bowel distention.  Will continue gentle tube feeds.
   Patient has had some loose stools today, checked C. diff to ensure that
   he is not infected given that he is on a large number of antibiotics
   and was  negative X3.  Rectal tube placed which seems to be improving
   his distention
   - Bowel regimen.
   -continue rectal tubes
   # R hand swelling
   - U/S of R arm
   # Hypothyroidism: Per most recent d/c summary, Synthroid at 50mcg daily
   or 25 IV.  Continued here.
   #GERD: PPI
   FEN: No IVF, replete electrolytes PRN, renal tube feeds.
   Prophylaxis: Subutaneous heparin; pneumoboots, PPI and bowel regimen

Summary:

The patient is a 56-year-old male with a history of asthma, diabetes, and hypertension, who presented with respiratory distress and pneumonia/ARDS from influenza A/H1N1. He has been in the ICU for several days and has been receiving mechanical ventilation, antibiotics, and other supportive care. He has had a tracheostomy and is currently on CPAP 10/5, 50%. His condition has been complicated by several issues, including fever, leukocytosis, acute renal failure, hyperglycemia, and a rash.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory status is unstable, and he is at risk for further deterioration.
2. Sepsis: The patient's fever and leukocytosis suggest the possibility of sepsis, which could lead to organ dysfunction and death.
3. Acute renal failure: The patient's creatinine level is elevated, and he has muddy casts on his urine sediment, suggesting a component of acute tubular necrosis (ATN).
4. Hyperglycemia: The patient's blood glucose level is elevated, and he is at risk for further complications, such as diabetic ketoacidosis.
5. Rhabdomyolysis: The patient's muscle weakness and elevated creatine kinase level suggest the possibility of rhabdomyolysis, which could lead to kidney failure and other complications.
6. Critical illness myopathy: The patient's muscle weakness and elevated creatine kinase level suggest the possibility of critical illness myopathy, which could lead to prolonged muscle weakness and other complications.
7. Pneumonia: The patient's pneumonia is complicated by the presence of influenza virus and possible bacterial superinfection.
8. Gastrointestinal bleeding: The patient's gastrointestinal bleeding is a potential complication of his pneumonia and sepsis.
9. Cardiovascular complications: The patient's tachycardia and hypertension suggest the possibility of cardiovascular complications, such as cardiomyopathy or arrhythmias.

Recommendations:

1. Continue to monitor the patient's respiratory status and adjust his ventilation settings as needed.
2. Consider starting antibiotics again if the patient's fever and leukocytosis persist.
3. Continue to manage the patient's hyperglycemia with insulin and other medications as needed.
4. Monitor the patient's renal function closely and consider dialysis if his creatinine level continues to rise.
5. Consider consulting a specialist, such as a nephrologist or a cardiologist, to help manage the patient's complex medical condition.
6. Continue to provide supportive care, such as nutrition and hydration, to help the patient recover from his illness.
7. Monitor the patient's mental status and provide psychological support to help him cope with his illness and treatment.
8. Consider involving the patient's family in his care and providing them with education and support to help them understand his condition and treatment.

   56M with asthma, DM, HTN presenting with respiratory distress and
   pneumonia/ARDS from influenza A/H1N1.
   Active issues:
   # Respiratory failure: Originially ARDS/sepsis combined w/ fluid
   overload and possible bacterial pneumonia.  Pt has now been trach'ed
   but didn't get PEG due to problems with EGD scope, so planning to go
   today. Continues now on CPAP 10/5, 50%.
   - Tomorrow consider trach mask trials, but will defer for now until
   after PEG placed
   - To get PEG today
   #Fevers/leukocytosis: Febrile to 101.1 two nights ago, pan-cultured,
   but no clear source and Cx's continue to be negative. Budding yeast in
   most recent sputum likely OP flora.  Currently off of antibiotics, and
   given lack of source we will not start any medications at this time.
   Has completed courses of Azithro, Peramivir, and continuing Vanc/Aztreo
   had been discussed. However, he has received full courses of these ABx
   and it seems reasonable to see how he does off of these now.
   - D/C all ABx yesterday but with lower threshold to restart if
   continues to be febrile or worsens. Would start with covering for gram
   negative per ID recs
   - His R IJ CVL does look a little erythematous, and should be pulled.
   Will get 2^nd PIV access today if possible and if so, can likely pull
   CVL as he doesn
t need it anymore currently
   # Acute drop in Hct: Did have a minor surgery yesterday but wouldn't
   think pt would lose a whole unit of blood.
   - Repeat Hct later this evening and continues to go down will transfuse
   # DM2: Was on insulin gtt until recently, but now switched to Glargine
   40U qhs and SSI. Has increasing SSI needs.
   - Will calculate insulin requirements once pt has taken a full day of
   nutrition either by PEG or by TF, in order to accurately calculate
   insulin requirements. Not today, as pt currently NPO for PEG today.
   # Critical illness myopathy:
   - Consult PT today
   Other stable issues:
   # Pneumonia: Patient has severe influenza with ARDS and possible
   bacterial superinfection.  He has completed his courses of antibiotics,
   and cultures have been negative besides influenza virus.  Stopped
   antibiotics yesterday.
    #Renal failure: Urine output and creatinine have improved.  Has muddy
   casts on urine sediment per renal, seems to have component of ATN.
   - Off of lasix gtt
   - Goal will be even for the day
   - Renal team has signed off
   # Eye redness and discharge: Per nursing, patient had contact in his
   right eye which was only removed the other day as there was no record
   that patient wore contacts. Unable to find contact in left eye.  Seen
   by ophthalmology who mentioned that contact was intentionally there.
   Also suggested some changes to his eye-drops and outpatient follow-up.
   Patient already has outpatient appointment set up
   - Prednisolone and tobramycin drops to R eye as prescribed.
   - Artificial tears ointment to both eyes
   #Tachycardia: Likely multifocal atrial tachycardia. Patient started on
   Lopressor 12.5 mg PO BID. Will not increase as patient tolerates lasix
   drip better when blood pressure slightly increased. If patient is
   tachycardic or hypertensive later in the day with decreased sedation,
   will increase this as needed.
   -Lopressor 12.5 mg PO BID
   # Rash: Rash seems to be improving now that zosyn d/c
d.  No signs of
   DRESS.  Has some signs of folliculitis today
   - Chlorhexadine wash on arms and legs to help prevent infection of
   follicles
   - Continue to monitor.
   #Abdominal distension: Seems to have poor motility with paralysis that
   leads to increasing bowel distention.  Will continue gentle tube feeds.
   Patient has had some loose stools today, checked C. diff to ensure that
   he is not infected given that he is on a large number of antibiotics
   and was  negative X3.  Rectal tube placed which seems to be improving
   his distention
   - Bowel regimen.
   -continue rectal tubes
   # R hand swelling
   - U/S of R arm
   # Hypothyroidism: Per most recent d/c summary, Synthroid at 50mcg daily
   or 25 IV.  Continued here.
   #GERD: PPI
   FEN: No IVF, replete electrolytes PRN, renal tube feeds.
 to get a
   PEG today
   Prophylaxis: Subutaneous heparin; pneumoboots, PPI and bowel regimen
   Access: peripherals, Aline, IJ Central line
 needs to be pulled, will
   do so after 2^nd PIV is placed
   Code:  Full Code as discussed with parents.
   Communication: Father and mother who are in to see him daily
   Disposition: pending improved respiratory status.

Based on the progress note, the patient is a 56-year-old male with a history of asthma, diabetes, and hypertension, who presented with respiratory distress and pneumonia/ARDS from influenza A/H1N1. The patient is currently intubated and on invasive ventilation, with a tracheostomy tube in place.

The patient's current medical issues include:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient has severe ARDS and possible bacterial superinfection, which has been treated with antibiotics. The patient is currently on CPAP 10/5, 50%.
2. Fever and leukocytosis: The patient has had fevers and leukocytosis, which has been treated with antibiotics. However, the source of the infection is unclear, and the patient is currently off antibiotics.
3. Acute drop in Hct: The patient's Hct has dropped significantly, which may be due to blood loss or other factors.
4. Critical illness myopathy: The patient has developed critical illness myopathy, which may be contributing to his respiratory failure.
5. Pneumonia: The patient has severe influenza with ARDS and possible bacterial superinfection.
6. Renal failure: The patient has acute renal failure, which may be due to ATN.
7. Eye redness and discharge: The patient has eye redness and discharge, which may be due to contact lens use.
8. Tachycardia: The patient has tachycardia, which may be due to multifocal atrial tachycardia.
9. Rash: The patient has a rash, which may be due to antibiotic use.
10. Abdominal distension: The patient has abdominal distension, which may be due to poor motility and paralysis.
11. R hand swelling: The patient has R hand swelling, which may be due to edema or other factors.
12. Hypothyroidism: The patient has hypothyroidism, which is being treated with Synthroid.
13. GERD: The patient has GERD, which is being treated with PPI.

The patient's labs show:

* WBC: 13.2
* Hct: 26.2
* Plt: 699
* Cr: 1.2
* TCO2: 29
* Glucose: 195
* Other labs: PT/PTT/INR: 13.5/51.1/1.2, ALT/AST: 31/46, Alk Phos/T Bili: 115/0.8, Amylase/Lipase: 34/10, Differential-Neuts: 79.0%, Band: 1.0%, Lymph: 9.0%, Mono: 6.0%, Eos: 0.0%, Lactic Acid: 1.2 mmol/L, Albumin: 2.3 g/dL, Ca++: 8.3 mg/dL, Mg++: 2.3 mg/dL, PO4: 4.2 mg/dL

The patient's imaging studies show:

* CXR: The patient's CXR shows worsening of the lung disease.
* EMG: The patient's EMG shows moderate sensorimotor polyneuropathy with predominantly axonal features.

The patient's plan includes:

* Continuing to monitor the patient's respiratory status and adjusting ventilation as needed.
* Continuing to treat the patient's fever and leukocytosis with antibiotics.
* Continuing to monitor the patient's Hct and transfusing as needed.
* Continuing to treat the patient's critical illness myopathy with physical therapy and medication.
* Continuing to monitor the patient's eye redness and discharge and treating as needed.
* Continuing to monitor the patient's tachycardia and treating as needed.
* Continuing to monitor the patient's rash and treating as needed.
* Continuing to monitor the patient's abdominal distension and treating as needed.
* Continuing to monitor the patient's R hand swelling and treating as needed.
* Continuing to treat the patient's hypothyroidism with Synthroid.
* Continuing to treat the patient's GERD with PPI.

The patient's code status is full code, and his disposition is pending improved respiratory status.

Summary:

The patient is a 56-year-old male admitted to the ICU with Influenza PNA and ARDS, who had a tracheostomy yesterday and is scheduled for a PEG today. He has been receiving various medications, including antibiotics, which were stopped due to stable WBC count. The patient has shown improvement in respiratory failure, and his vent weaning is being continued. He is at risk for aspiration due to his inability to protect his airway.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Respiratory Failure: The patient's respiratory failure is already severe, and weaning off the vent is being attempted. However, there is a risk of respiratory failure worsening, which could lead to further complications.
2. Sepsis: The patient has been off antibiotics for some time, and his WBC count is stable. However, there is still a risk of sepsis developing, which could lead to organ dysfunction and poor outcomes.
3. Renal Failure: The patient's creatinine levels are elevated, indicating possible acute renal failure. This could lead to further complications, such as electrolyte imbalances and acidosis.
4. Neurological Complications: The patient has critical illness polyneuropathy, which could lead to further neurological complications, such as weakness, paralysis, or respiratory failure.
5. Constipation: The patient's constipation could lead to further complications, such as bowel obstruction, perforation, or sepsis.
6. Hyperglycemia: The patient's hyperglycemia could lead to further complications, such as ketoacidosis, hyperosmolar nonketotic coma, or increased risk of infections.
7. Pneumonia: The patient has pneumonia, which could lead to further complications, such as respiratory failure, sepsis, or death.
8. Airway Complications: The patient's inability to protect his airway increases the risk of aspiration, which could lead to respiratory failure, sepsis, or death.

It is essential to closely monitor the patient's condition and adjust his treatment plan accordingly to prevent these potential complications and improve his outcomes.

TITLE:
   Chief Complaint: ARDS
   24 Hour Events:
   At around midnight, patient started desaturating in the setting of
   getting 400ml of IVF after being NPO for >24hours.  His saturation went
   to 80%, he was tachypneic to 30-40 and tachycardic to 130's.  Was alert
   and anxious.  He was put back on CMV/Assist and had to put PEEP to 12
   and FiO2 to 100% to get sats up.
   Patient put in reverse trendelenberg, lasix 80 was given, fentanyl
   boluses and versed boluses were given for sedation.  CXR showed marked
   pulm edema.  His settings were able to be weaned to PEEP 5 abd FiO2
   50%.  Still tachycardic and tachypneic.

   Microbiology: [**2111-12-23**]  Blood Culture, Routine-PENDING INPATIENT
   [**2111-12-23**]  URINE CULTURE-PENDING INPATIENT
   [**2111-12-22**]  CATHETER TIP-IV WOUND CULTURE-PENDING
   Assessment and Plan
   56M with asthma, DM, HTN presenting with respiratory distress and
   pneumonia/ARDS from influenza A/H1N1.
   .
   # New Respiratory failure: Originially ARDS/sepsis combined w/ fluid
   overload and possible bacterial pneumonia.  Pt had a trach placed.  Has
   been off sedating drips for 2 days and had been doing well on pressure
   support.  Patient experienced distress in setting of receiving 400ml of
   IVF after being NPO for greater than 24 hours.  Vents settings adjusted
   and patient sedated.  Repeated CXR which showed pulm edema and gave
   lasix.  Bed in reverse T.  Patient improved saturation (100%FiO2 and 12
   of PEEP to 50% and 5 PEEP) but is still agitated, tachypneic, and
   tachycardic.   Patient could have VAP esp in setting of recent trach
   placement and fever spike this morning.
   - Restart lasix drip
   - F/u cultures of blood, sputum, and urine
   - Restart antibiotics: vanc, cefipime, and cipro for  MRSA and double
   pseudomonas coverage if spikes again or if culture begin to grow
   something.
   - Nebulizer treatments and suctioning
   - Daily CXR
   - increase sedation- restart fentanyl and propofol drip.
   .
   #Fevers/leukocytosis: Febrile to 101.4 this morning.  Pan-cultured, but
   no clear source and Cx's negative this morning.  Had been spiking
   fevers recently despite clinical improvement.  Righ IJ was pulled last
   night and tip will be cultured.  Currently off of antibiotics, and
   given lack of source we will not start any medications at this time.
   Has completed courses of Azithro, Peramivir, and continuing Vanc/Aztreo
   had been discussed. However, he has received full courses of these ABx
   and it seems reasonable to see how he does off of these now.
   - D/C all ABx 2days ago.  Will restart if decompensates or if cultures
   are revealing.   Would start with covering for gram negative per ID
   recs
   - Follow up all cultures, including catheter tip
   .
   # Acute drop in Hct: Did have a minor surgery yesterday but wouldn't
   think pt would lose a whole unit of blood.  Repeat Hcts have been
   stable.  Will continue to follow and transfuse if below 25 so that PEG
   can be placed
   - q12 hour Hct
   -transfuse if below 25
    .
   # DM2: Was on insulin gtt until recently, but now switched to Glargine
   40U qhs and SSI. Has increasing SSI needs.
   - Will calculate insulin requirements once pt has taken a full day of
   nutrition either by PEG or by TF, in order to accurately calculate
   insulin requirements. Not today, as pt currently NPO for PEG today.
   .
   # Critical illness myopathy:
   - Consult PT today
   .
   Other stable issues:
    #Renal failure: Urine output and creatinine have improved.  Has muddy
   casts on urine sediment per renal, seems to have component of ATN.  Has
   really improved with treatment and improvement of ARDS
   - Off of lasix gtt; will restart today
   - Renal team has signed off
   .
   # Eye redness and discharge: Per nursing, patient had contact in his
   right eye which was only removed the other day as there was no record
   that patient wore contacts. Unable to find contact in left eye.  Seen
   by ophthalmology who mentioned that contact was intentionally there.
   Also suggested some changes to his eye-drops and outpatient follow-up.
   Patient already has outpatient appointment set up
   - Prednisolone and tobramycin drops to R eye as prescribed.
   - Artificial tears ointment to both eyes
   .
   #Tachycardia: Likely multifocal atrial tachycardia. Patient started on
   Lopressor 12.5 mg PO BID. Will not increase as patient tolerates lasix
   drip better when blood pressure slightly increased. If patient is
   tachycardic or hypertensive later in the day with decreased sedation,
   will increase this as needed.
   -Lopressor 12.5 mg PO BID
   .
   # Rash: Rash seems to be improving now that zosyn d/c
d.  No signs of
   DRESS.  Has some signs of folliculitis today
   - Chlorhexadine wash on arms and legs to help prevent infection of
   follicles
   - Continue to monitor.
   .
   #Abdominal distension: Seems to have poor motility with paralysis that
   leads to increasing bowel distention.  Will continue gentle tube feeds.

   .

   no clear source and Cx's negative this morning.  Had been spiking
   fevers recently despite clinical improvement.  Righ IJ was pulled last

   given lack of source we will not start any medications at this time.

   .

    #Renal failure: Urine output and creatinine have improved.  Has muddy

d.  No signs of

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 56-year-old male with a chief complaint of ARDS, pneumonia, and respiratory distress. He has a history of asthma, DM, and HTN.

The patient's current condition is as follows:

* Respiratory: The patient is still tachypneic and tachycardic, requiring ventilation with CMV/ASSIST/AutoFlow mode. His oxygen saturation is 100% on 50% FiO2 and 5 cmH2O PEEP.
* Cardiovascular: The patient's heart rate is 135 beats per minute, and his blood pressure is 108/75 mmHg.
* Renal: The patient's urine output has improved, and his creatinine level has decreased. However, he still has muddy casts on his urine sediment, suggesting a component of acute tubular necrosis (ATN).
* Gastrointestinal: The patient has poor motility due to paralysis, leading to increasing bowel distension. He has had loose stools today, and a rectal tube has been placed to improve his distension.
* Endocrine: The patient has hypothyroidism, and he is receiving Synthroid at 50mcg daily.
* Other issues: The patient has a fever of 101.4°F, and he is pan-cultured with new CXR. He has a rash that is improving, and he has signs of folliculitis.

Potential medical complications that can arise include:

* Ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP) due to the recent tracheostomy placement and fever spike this morning.
* Bacterial pneumonia, given the patient's fever and diffuse patchiness on CXR.
* Acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS) due to the patient's respiratory failure and fluid overload.
* Sepsis, given the patient's fever and leukocytosis.
* Renal failure, given the patient's decreased urine output and creatinine level.
* Gastrointestinal bleeding, given the patient's poor motility and bowel distension.
* Hypothyroidism, given the patient's recent thyroidectomy and hypothyroidism diagnosis.
* Folliculitis, given the patient's rash and signs of folliculitis.

The patient's treatment plan includes:

* Restarting lasix drip to improve his fluid overload.
* Following up on cultures of blood, sputum, and urine to determine the source of the patient's fever and leukocytosis.
* Restarting antibiotics if the patient's cultures are positive.
* Providing nebulizer treatments and suctioning to help improve the patient's respiratory status.
* Increasing sedation with fentanyl and propofol drip to help manage the patient's agitation and tachycardia.
* Monitoring the patient's electrolyte levels and renal function to ensure that they are within normal limits.
* Providing gentle tube feeds to help improve the patient's nutritional status.
* Continuing to monitor the patient's respiratory, cardiovascular, and gastrointestinal status to ensure that they are improving and not worsening.

Summary:

The patient is a 56-year-old male with a history of asthma, diabetes, and hypertension, who presented with respiratory distress and pneumonia/ARDS due to influenza A/H1N1. He was initially intubated and placed on mechanical ventilation with a tracheostomy. The patient had a significant drop in oxygen saturation after receiving 400ml of IV fluids, requiring adjustments to his ventilator settings and sedation. He has been experiencing fevers, tachycardia, and tachypnea, and has been pan-cultured with new CXR showing pulmonary edema.

The patient's condition is complex, with multiple potential complications, including:

1. Ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP): Given the patient's recent tracheostomy and fever spike, there is a risk of VAP.
2. Sepsis: The patient's fever and tachycardia may indicate sepsis, which could be caused by a variety of pathogens.
3. Respiratory failure: The patient's ARDS and pneumonia may lead to prolonged respiratory failure.
4. Fluid overload: The patient's pulmonary edema and fluid overload may require ongoing management.
5. Gastrointestinal issues: The patient has abdominal distension, which may be related to poor motility and paralysis, and has had loose stools, which may indicate C. diff infection.
6. Renal failure: The patient has had acute kidney injury, which has improved with treatment, but may still require ongoing management.
7. Critical illness myopathy: The patient's prolonged critical illness may lead to muscle weakness and myopathy.
8. Eye issues: The patient has eye redness and discharge, which may be related to contact lens use.
9. Tachycardia: The patient's tachycardia may be related to a variety of factors, including sepsis, hypothyroidism, and critical illness myopathy.
10. Rash: The patient has a rash, which may be related to medication or infection.

Plan:

1. Restart lasix drip to manage fluid overload.
2. F/u cultures of blood, sputum, and urine to identify potential pathogens.
3. Restart antibiotics: vanc, cefipime, and cipro for MRSA and double pseudomonas coverage if spikes again or if cultures begin to grow something.
4. Nebulizer treatments and suctioning to manage respiratory issues.
5. Daily CXR to monitor respiratory status.
6. Increase sedation- restart fentanyl and propofol drip.
7. Monitor for VAP and sepsis.
8. Continue to manage gastrointestinal issues, including bowel regimen and rectal tubes.
9. Monitor renal function and adjust management as needed.
10. Consult PT to evaluate for critical illness myopathy.
11. Continue to monitor eye issues and adjust management as needed.
12. Monitor tachycardia and adjust management as needed.
13. Continue to monitor rash and adjust management as needed.

The patient's condition is complex and requires ongoing management to address multiple potential complications. Close monitoring and adjustments to management as needed will be necessary to optimize the patient's outcome.

   Assessment and Plan
   56M with asthma, DM, HTN presenting with respiratory distress and
   pneumonia/ARDS from influenza A/H1N1.
   .
   # New Respiratory failure: Originally ARDS/sepsis combined w/ fluid
   overload and possible bacterial pneumonia. Pt had a trach placed.  Has
   been off sedating drips for 2 days and had been doing well on pressure
   support.  Patient experienced distress in setting of receiving 400ml of
   IVF after being NPO for greater than 24 hours.  Vent settings adjusted
   and patient sedated.  Repeated CXR which showed pulmonary edema and
   gave lasix.  Bed in reverse Trendelenberg.  Patient improved saturation
   (100%FiO2 and 12 of PEEP to 50% and 5 PEEP) but is still agitated,
   tachypneic, and tachycardic.   Patient could have VAP especially in
   setting of recent trach placement and fever spike this morning.
   - Hold Lasix for now, pursue infectious source and restart diuresis
   possibly in the future.
   - F/u cultures of blood, sputum, and urine
   - Restart antibiotics: vanc, cefipime, and cipro for MRSA and double
   pseudomonas coverage
   - Nebulizer treatments and suctioning
   - Daily CXR
   - Sedation: bolus sedation with fentanyl and midazolam.
   - mini-BAL
   .
   #Fevers/leukocytosis: Febrile to 101.4 this morning.  Pan-cultured, but
   no clear source and Cx's negative this morning.  Had been spiking
   fevers recently despite clinical improvement.  Right IJ was pulled last
   night and tip will be cultured.  Currently off of antibiotics, and
   given lack of source we will not start any medications at this time.
   Has completed courses of Azithro, Peramivir, and continuing Vanc/Aztreo
   had been discussed. However, he had  received full courses of these ABx
   and it seemed reasonable to see how he did off of these; but now, given
   fever, worsening respiratory status, and lower BP, want to start
   empiric coverage.
   - Start antibiotics for empiric coverage = start vancomycin, cefepime,
   ciprofloxacin
   - Mini-BAL
   - Follow up all cultures, including catheter tip
   .
   # Acute drop in Hct: Did have a minor surgery yesterday but wouldn't
   think pt would lose a whole unit of blood.  Repeat Hcts have been
   stable.  Will continue to follow and transfuse if below 25 so that PEG
   can be placed.
   - q12 hour Hct
   -transfuse if below 25
    .
   # DM2: Was on insulin gtt until recently, but now switched to Glargine
   40U qhs and SSI. Has increasing SSI needs.
   - Will calculate insulin requirements once pt has taken a full day of
   nutrition either by PEG or by TF, in order to accurately calculate
   insulin requirements. Not today, as pt currently NPO for PEG today.
   SSI.
   .
   #PEG placement: Surgery and GI have deferred placement of PEG to IR b/c
   of h/o volvulus, low albumin, and low Hcts.  IR so far has agreed to do
   procedure, but will wait until clinically improves.
   - Reschedule gastrostomy w/ IR when improves clinically.
   # Critical illness myopathy:
   - Consult PT today
   .
   Other stable issues:
    #Renal failure: Urine output and creatinine have improved.  Has muddy
   casts on urine sediment per renal, seems to have component of ATN.  Has
   really improved with treatment and improvement of ARDS.
   - Off of lasix gtt; consider Lasix later today pending I
s and O
   - Renal team has signed off
   .
   # Eye redness and discharge: Per nursing, patient had contact in his
   right eye which was only removed the other day as there was no record
   that patient wore contacts. Unable to find contact in left eye.  Seen
   by ophthalmology who mentioned that contact was intentionally there.
   Also suggested some changes to his eye-drops and outpatient follow-up.
   Patient already has outpatient appointment set up.
   - Prednisolone and tobramycin drops to R eye as prescribed.
   - Artificial tears ointment to both eyes
   .
   #Tachycardia: Likely multifocal atrial tachycardia. Patient started
   previously on Lopressor; however now with borderline blood pressure.
   - Discontinue Lopressor to see if treating infection improves this.
   .
   # Rash: Rash seems to be improving now that zosyn d/c
d.  No signs of
   DRESS.  Has some signs of folliculitis today
   - Chlorhexadine wash on arms and legs to help prevent infection of
   follicles
   - Continue to monitor.
   .
   #Abdominal distension: Seems to have poor motility with paralysis that
   leads to increasing bowel distention.  Will continue gentle tube feeds.
   Patient has had some loose stools today, checked C. diff to ensure that
   he is not infected given that he is on a large number of antibiotics
   and was negative X3.  Rectal tube placed which seems to be improving
   his distention.
   - Bowel regimen.
   -Continue rectal tube
   .
   # Hypothyroidism: Per most recent d/c summary, Synthroid at 50mcg daily
   or 25 IV.  Continued here.
   .
   #GERD: PPI
   .
   FEN: No IVF, replete electrolytes PRN, renal tube feeds. Consider PEG
   placement soon but not today (by IR; not by GI or surgery). NG tube
   placement today.
   Prophylaxis: Subcutaneous heparin; pneumoboots, PPI and bowel regimen
   Access: 2 peripherals, A-line (might need to re-wire today), IJ Central
   line pulled.
   Code:  Full Code as discussed with parents.
   Communication: Father and mother who are in to see him daily.
   Disposition: Pending improved respiratory status.<|eot_id|><|start_header_id|>assistant<|end_header_id|>

Based on the physician's daily progress note, the patient is a 56-year-old male with a history of asthma, diabetes, and hypertension, who presented with respiratory distress and pneumonia/ARDS due to influenza A/H1N1. The patient has been experiencing significant respiratory failure, requiring mechanical ventilation and sedation.

The patient's 24-hour events note that he desaturated at midnight, likely due to the administration of 400ml of IV fluid after being NPO for over 24 hours. His oxygen saturation decreased to 80%, and he became tachypneic and tachycardic. The patient was placed back on CMV/Assist and required increased PEEP and FiO2 to maintain oxygen saturation.

The patient's current condition is as follows:

* Respiratory status: The patient is still agitated, tachypneic, and tachycardic, despite improvements in his oxygen saturation.
* Cardiovascular status: The patient's blood pressure is borderline, and he is at risk for hypotension.
* Hemodynamic status: The patient's cardiac index is decreased, and he is at risk for cardiac failure.
* Neurological status: The patient is more alert than previously, but not truly responding to commands.
* Renal status: The patient's urine output has improved, but he still has muddy casts on his urine sediment, suggesting a component of acute tubular necrosis (ATN).
* Gastrointestinal status: The patient has abdominal distension, likely due to poor motility, and has had some loose stools today.
* Endocrine status: The patient has hypothyroidism and is taking Synthroid.

Potential medical complications that can arise include:

* Ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP) due to the patient's recent tracheostomy and fever spike this morning.
* Sepsis due to the patient's recent antibiotic courses and ongoing infection.
* Respiratory failure due to the patient's ongoing respiratory distress and ARDS.
* Cardiac failure due to the patient's borderline blood pressure and decreased cardiac index.
* Renal failure due to the patient's ongoing ATN and decreased urine output.
* Gastrointestinal complications due to the patient's poor motility and abdominal distension.
* Endocrine complications due to the patient's hypothyroidism and ongoing medication.

The plan of care includes:

* Holding Lasix for now and pursuing an infectious source.
* Restarting antibiotics with vancomycin, cefepime, and ciprofloxacin for empiric coverage.
* Continuing nebulizer treatments and suctioning.
* Performing daily CXR.
* Restarting sedation with fentanyl and midazolam.
* Considering mini-BAL.
* Transfusing blood products if the patient's Hct drops below 25.
* Rescheduling PEG placement with IR when the patient improves clinically.
* Consulting PT for critical illness myopathy.
* Monitoring the patient's eye redness and discharge, and adjusting treatment as needed.
* Discontinuing Lopressor to see if treating infection improves the patient's tachycardia.
* Continuing to monitor the patient's rash and folliculitis, and adjusting treatment as needed.
* Continuing gentle tube feeds and rectal tube placement to manage the patient's abdominal distension.
* Continuing thyroid medication and GERD treatment.
* Considering PEG placement soon, but not today, and planning for NG tube placement today.

   - Tomorrow consider trach mask trials, but will defer for now until

   CVL as he doesn
t need it anymore currently

   40U qhs and SSI. Has increasing SSI needs.

   insulin requirements. Not today, as pt currently NPO for PEG today.

   - Consult PT today

d.  No signs of

Summary:

The patient is a 56-year-old male with a history of asthma, diabetes, and hypertension who was admitted to the ICU with respiratory distress and pneumonia/ARDS due to influenza A/H1N1. He has been on mechanical ventilation and has had multiple episodes of desaturation, tachypnea, and tachycardia. He has also developed fevers, leukocytosis, and a possible bacterial superinfection.

The patient's current status is as follows:

* Respiratory support: He is on pressure support ventilation with a PEEP of 5 cmH2O and an FiO2 of 50%.
* Hemodynamic monitoring: His blood pressure is 108/75 mmHg, and his heart rate is 135 beats per minute.
* Fluid balance: He has received 905 mL of IV fluids and has a total fluid balance of -350 mL.
* Laboratory results: His WBC count is 13.2, his Hct is 26.4%, and his platelet count is 955 K/uL.
* Imaging: His CXR shows diffuse patchiness likely due to pulmonary edema, ARDS, or infection.

Potential medical complications:

* Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory status is critical, and he may develop further respiratory failure if his oxygenation and ventilation requirements are not met.
* Sepsis: The patient's fevers, leukocytosis, and possible bacterial superinfection may indicate sepsis, which can lead to organ dysfunction and failure.
* Renal failure: The patient's urine output and creatinine levels are improving, but he may still develop renal failure if his fluid and electrolyte balance is not carefully managed.
* Critical illness myopathy: The patient's prolonged mechanical ventilation and critical illness may lead to critical illness myopathy, which can cause muscle weakness and paralysis.
* Pneumonia: The patient's pneumonia may worsen if he is not adequately treated with antibiotics and if he develops further respiratory failure.
* Eye redness and discharge: The patient's eye redness and discharge may be due to a contact lens or infection, and he may require further evaluation and treatment.
* Tachycardia: The patient's tachycardia may be due to his critical illness, and he may require further evaluation and treatment to manage his heart rate.
* Rash: The patient's rash may be due to an allergic reaction or infection, and he may require further evaluation and treatment to manage his skin lesions.
* Abdominal distension: The patient's abdominal distension may be due to poor motility and paralysis, and he may require further evaluation and treatment to manage his bowel function.
* R hand swelling: The patient's R hand swelling may be due to an underlying condition, and he may require further evaluation and treatment to manage his hand swelling.
* Hypothyroidism: The patient's hypothyroidism may require further evaluation and treatment to manage his thyroid function.
* GERD: The patient's GERD may require further evaluation and treatment to manage his symptoms.

Plan:

* Continue to monitor the patient's respiratory status and adjust his ventilator settings as needed.
* Continue to manage his fluid and electrolyte balance to prevent further complications.
* Consider tracheostomy trials and placement of a PEG tube to improve his nutritional status.
* Continue to manage his sepsis and potential bacterial superinfection with antibiotics and further evaluation.
* Consider consulting a critical care physician to manage his critical illness myopathy and other potential complications.
* Continue to monitor his eye redness and discharge and provide further treatment as needed.
* Continue to manage his tachycardia and other cardiovascular complications.
* Continue to monitor his rash and provide further treatment as needed.
* Continue to manage his abdominal distension and other gastrointestinal complications.
* Continue to monitor his R hand swelling and provide further treatment as needed.
* Continue to manage his hypothyroidism and other endocrine complications.
* Continue to manage his GERD and other gastrointestinal complications.

TITLE:

   getting 400ml of IVF after being NPO for >24hours.  His saturation went

   and anxious.  He was put back on CMV/Assist and had to put PEEP to 12

   pulmonary edema.  His settings were able to be weaned to PEEP 5 and
   FiO2 50% this morning.  Still tachycardic and tachypneic.
