   Assessment and Plan
   56M with asthma, DM, HTN presenting with respiratory distress and
   pneumonia/ARDS from influenza A/H1N1.
   .
   # New Respiratory failure: Originally ARDS/sepsis combined w/ fluid
   overload and possible bacterial pneumonia. Pt had a trach placed.  Has
   been off sedating drips for 2 days and had been doing well on pressure
   support.  Patient experienced distress in setting of receiving 400ml of
   IVF after being NPO for greater than 24 hours.  Vent settings adjusted
   and patient sedated.  Repeated CXR which showed pulmonary edema and
   gave lasix.  Bed in reverse Trendelenberg.  Patient improved saturation
   (100%FiO2 and 12 of PEEP to 50% and 5 PEEP) but is still agitated,
   tachypneic, and tachycardic.   Patient could have VAP especially in
   setting of recent trach placement and fever spike this morning.
   - Consider Lasix this afternoon, pending I
s and O
s trend
   - F/u cultures of blood, sputum, and urine
   - Restart antibiotics: vanc, cefipime, and cipro for MRSA and double
   pseudomonas coverage
   - Nebulizer treatments and suctioning
   - Daily CXR
   - Sedation: bolus sedation with fentanyl and midazolam.
   .
   #Fevers/leukocytosis: Febrile to 101.4 this morning.  Pan-cultured, but
   no clear source and Cx's negative this morning.  Had been spiking
   fevers recently despite clinical improvement.  Right IJ was pulled last
   night and tip will be cultured.  Currently off of antibiotics, and
   given lack of source we will not start any medications at this time.
   Has completed courses of Azithro, Peramivir, and continuing Vanc/Aztreo
   had been discussed. However, he had  received full courses of these ABx
   and it seemed reasonable to see how he did off of these; but now, given
   fever, worsening respiratory status, and lower BP, want to start
   empiric coverage.
   - Start antibiotics for empiric coverage = start vancomycin, cefepime,
   ciprofloxacin
   - Mini-BAL
   - Follow up all cultures, including catheter tip
   .
   # Acute drop in Hct: Did have a minor surgery yesterday but wouldn't
   think pt would lose a whole unit of blood.  Repeat Hcts have been
   stable.  Will continue to follow and transfuse if below 25 so that PEG
   can be placed.
   - q12 hour Hct
   -transfuse if below 25
    .
   # DM2: Was on insulin gtt until recently, but now switched to Glargine
   40U qhs and SSI. Has increasing SSI needs.
   - Will calculate insulin requirements once pt has taken a full day of
   nutrition either by PEG or by TF, in order to accurately calculate
   insulin requirements. Not today, as pt currently NPO for PEG today.
   SSI.
   .
   # Critical illness myopathy:
   - Consult PT today
   .
   Other stable issues:
    #Renal failure: Urine output and creatinine have improved.  Has muddy
   casts on urine sediment per renal, seems to have component of ATN.  Has
   really improved with treatment and improvement of ARDS.
   - Off of lasix gtt; consider Lasix later today pending I
s and O
   - Renal team has signed off
   .
   # Eye redness and discharge: Per nursing, patient had contact in his
   right eye which was only removed the other day as there was no record
   that patient wore contacts. Unable to find contact in left eye.  Seen
   by ophthalmology who mentioned that contact was intentionally there.
   Also suggested some changes to his eye-drops and outpatient follow-up.
   Patient already has outpatient appointment set up.
   - Prednisolone and tobramycin drops to R eye as prescribed.
   - Artificial tears ointment to both eyes
   .
   #Tachycardia: Likely multifocal atrial tachycardia. Patient started
   previously on Lopressor; however now with borderline blood pressure.
   - Discontinue Lopressor
   .
   # Rash: Rash seems to be improving now that zosyn d/c
d.  No signs of
   DRESS.  Has some signs of folliculitis today
   - Chlorhexadine wash on arms and legs to help prevent infection of
   follicles
   - Continue to monitor.
   .
   #Abdominal distension: Seems to have poor motility with paralysis that
   leads to increasing bowel distention.  Will continue gentle tube feeds.
   Patient has had some loose stools today, checked C. diff to ensure that
   he is not infected given that he is on a large number of antibiotics
   and was negative X3.  Rectal tube placed which seems to be improving
   his distention.
   - Bowel regimen.
   -Continue rectal tube
   .
   # Hypothyroidism: Per most recent d/c summary, Synthroid at 50mcg daily
   or 25 IV.  Continued here.
   .
   #GERD: PPI
   .
   FEN: No IVF, replete electrolytes PRN, renal tube feeds. Consider PEG
   placement soon but not today (by IR; not by GI or surgery). NG tube
   placement today.
   Prophylaxis: Subcutaneous heparin; pneumoboots, PPI and bowel regimen
   Access: 2 peripherals, A-line (might need to re-wire today), IJ Central
   line pulled.
   Code:  Full Code as discussed with parents.
   Communication: Father and mother who are in to see him daily.
   Disposition: Pending improved respiratory status.

   Assessment and Plan
   56M with asthma, DM, HTN presenting with respiratory distress and
   pneumonia/ARDS from influenza A/H1N1.
   .
   # New Respiratory failure: Originally ARDS/sepsis combined w/ fluid
   overload and possible bacterial pneumonia. Pt had a trach placed.  Has
   been off sedating drips for 2 days and had been doing well on pressure
   support.  Patient experienced distress in setting of receiving 400ml of
   IVF after being NPO for greater than 24 hours.  Vent settings adjusted
   and patient sedated.  Repeated CXR which showed pulmonary edema and
   gave lasix.  Bed in reverse Trendelenberg.  Patient improved saturation
   (100%FiO2 and 12 of PEEP to 50% and 5 PEEP) but is still agitated,
   tachypneic, and tachycardic.   Patient could have VAP especially in
   setting of recent trach placement and fever spike this morning.
   - Consider Lasix this afternoon, pending I
s and O
s trend
   - F/u cultures of blood, sputum, and urine
   - Restart antibiotics: vanc, cefipime, and cipro for MRSA and double
   pseudomonas coverage
   - Nebulizer treatments and suctioning
   - Daily CXR
   - Sedation: bolus sedation with fentanyl and midazolam.
   .
   #Fevers/leukocytosis: Febrile to 101.4 this morning.  Pan-cultured, but
   no clear source and Cx's negative this morning.  Had been spiking
   fevers recently despite clinical improvement.  Right IJ was pulled last
   night and tip will be cultured.  Currently off of antibiotics, and
   given lack of source we will not start any medications at this time.
   Has completed courses of Azithro, Peramivir, and continuing Vanc/Aztreo
   had been discussed. However, he had  received full courses of these ABx
   and it seemed reasonable to see how he did off of these; but now, given
   fever, worsening respiratory status, and lower BP, want to start
   empiric coverage.
   - Start antibiotics for empiric coverage = start vancomycin, cefepime,
   ciprofloxacin
   - Mini-BAL
   - Follow up all cultures, including catheter tip
   .
   # Acute drop in Hct: Did have a minor surgery yesterday but wouldn't
   think pt would lose a whole unit of blood.  Repeat Hcts have been
   stable.  Will continue to follow and transfuse if below 25 so that PEG
   can be placed.
   - q12 hour Hct
   -transfuse if below 25
    .
   # DM2: Was on insulin gtt until recently, but now switched to Glargine
   40U qhs and SSI. Has increasing SSI needs.
   - Will calculate insulin requirements once pt has taken a full day of
   nutrition either by PEG or by TF, in order to accurately calculate
   insulin requirements. Not today, as pt currently NPO for PEG today.
   SSI.
   .
   # Critical illness myopathy:
   - Consult PT today
   .
   Other stable issues:
    #Renal failure: Urine output and creatinine have improved.  Has muddy
   casts on urine sediment per renal, seems to have component of ATN.  Has
   really improved with treatment and improvement of ARDS.
   - Off of lasix gtt; consider Lasix later today pending I
s and O
   - Renal team has signed off
   .
   # Eye redness and discharge: Per nursing, patient had contact in his
   right eye which was only removed the other day as there was no record
   that patient wore contacts. Unable to find contact in left eye.  Seen
   by ophthalmology who mentioned that contact was intentionally there.
   Also suggested some changes to his eye-drops and outpatient follow-up.
   Patient already has outpatient appointment set up.
   - Prednisolone and tobramycin drops to R eye as prescribed.
   - Artificial tears ointment to both eyes
   .
   #Tachycardia: Likely multifocal atrial tachycardia. Patient started
   previously on Lopressor; however now with borderline blood pressure.
   - Discontinue Lopressor
   .
   # Rash: Rash seems to be improving now that zosyn d/c
d.  No signs of
   DRESS.  Has some signs of folliculitis today
   - Chlorhexadine wash on arms and legs to help prevent infection of
   follicles
   - Continue to monitor.
   .
   #Abdominal distension: Seems to have poor motility with paralysis that
   leads to increasing bowel distention.  Will continue gentle tube feeds.
   Patient has had some loose stools today, checked C. diff to ensure that
   he is not infected given that he is on a large number of antibiotics
   and was negative X3.  Rectal tube placed which seems to be improving
   his distention.
   - Bowel regimen.
   -Continue rectal tube
   .
   # Hypothyroidism: Per most recent d/c summary, Synthroid at 50mcg daily
   or 25 IV.  Continued here.
   .
   #GERD: PPI
   .
   FEN: No IVF, replete electrolytes PRN, renal tube feeds. Consider PEG
   placement soon but not today (by IR; not by GI or surgery). NG tube
   placement today.
   Prophylaxis: Subcutaneous heparin; pneumoboots, PPI and bowel regimen
   Access: 2 peripherals, A-line (might need to re-wire today), IJ Central
   line pulled.
   Code:  Full Code as discussed with parents.
   Communication: Father and mother who are in to see him daily.
   Disposition: Pending improved respiratory status.<|eot_id|><|start_header_id|>assistant<|end_header_id|>

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 56-year-old male with a complex medical history, including asthma, diabetes, hypertension, and a recent tracheostomy. He was admitted with respiratory distress and pneumonia/ARDS due to influenza A/H1N1.

The patient experienced a significant deterioration in his condition overnight, with desaturation to 80% after receiving 400ml of IV fluid, followed by a fever to 101.4°F. He was placed back on continuous positive airway pressure (CPAP) and required sedation with fentanyl and midazolam.

The patient's current status is as follows:

* Respiratory: Tachypneic and tachycardic, with a PaO2/FiO2 ratio of 178. He is still agitated and requires sedation.
* Cardiovascular: Tachycardic with a heart rate of 135 beats per minute.
* Renal: Urine output has improved, and the patient has muddy casts on urine sediment, suggesting a component of acute tubular necrosis (ATN).
* Hematology: Hemoglobin level has dropped by 1 unit, and the patient is being transfused if below 25%.
* Endocrine: The patient has diabetes mellitus type 2 and is being managed with insulin glargine 40U qhs and sliding scale insulin.
* Gastrointestinal: The patient has abdominal distension, likely due to poor motility and paralysis, and is receiving gentle tube feeds. He has also had some loose stools and a rectal tube has been placed to improve distention.
* Skin: The patient has a rash that is improving, but he has some signs of folliculitis.
* Eye: The patient has eye redness and discharge, and is being treated with prednisolone and tobramycin drops.

Potential medical complications that may arise include:

* Ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP) due to the recent tracheostomy and prolonged mechanical ventilation.
* Sepsis or septic shock due to the patient's fever and tachycardia.
* Acute kidney injury (AKI) or worsening of existing renal failure due to the patient's underlying condition and potential ATN.
* Pneumonia or other respiratory infections due to the patient's immunocompromised state and prolonged mechanical ventilation.
* Deep vein thrombosis (DVT) or pulmonary embolism (PE) due to the patient's prolonged immobility and risk factors.
* Wound infection or dehiscence due to the patient's recent surgery and prolonged hospitalization.

The patient's plan of care includes:

* Empiric antibiotic coverage for possible bacterial pneumonia or sepsis.
* Mini-BAL to evaluate the patient's respiratory status.
* Follow-up cultures, including catheter tip culture.
* Repeat Hct and transfusion if below 25%.
* Calculation of insulin requirements once the patient has taken a full day of nutrition.
* Consult with physical therapy to address the patient's critical illness myopathy.
* Continued gentle tube feeds and rectal tube placement to manage the patient's abdominal distension.
* Prophylaxis with subcutaneous heparin and pneumoboots.
* Consideration of PEG placement soon, but not today.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 56-year-old man with Down's syndrome, admitted with influenza A and acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS). The patient's condition has deteriorated, with worsening oxygenation, tachycardia, and tachypnea. He has developed pulmonary edema, and his temperature has spiked to 101.4°F (38.6°C).

The patient has been receiving various medications, including antibiotics, sedatives, and vasopressors. He has also been receiving mechanical ventilation and has had multiple blood products transfused.

Potential medical complications that can arise from the patient's condition include:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's worsening oxygenation and tachypnea suggest that he may be at risk for respiratory failure, which can lead to further deterioration and potentially life-threatening complications.
2. Sepsis: The patient's fever, tachycardia, and tachypnea are consistent with sepsis, which can lead to organ dysfunction and potentially life-threatening complications.
3. Renal failure: The patient's elevated creatinine levels and decreased urine output suggest that he may be at risk for acute kidney injury or renal failure.
4. Constipation: The patient's use of laxatives and stool softeners suggests that he may be at risk for constipation, which can lead to further complications such as bowel obstruction or perforation.
5. Hyperglycemia: The patient's elevated glucose levels suggest that he may be at risk for hyperglycemia, which can lead to further complications such as diabetic ketoacidosis or nonketotic hyperglycemic hyperosmolar syndrome.
6. Pneumonia: The patient's chest X-ray suggests that he may have developed pneumonia, which can lead to further complications such as respiratory failure, sepsis, and mortality.
7. Sternal fracture: The patient's chest X-ray also suggests that he may have a sternal fracture, which can lead to further complications such as respiratory distress, mediastinitis, and mortality.

In light of these potential complications, it is essential to closely monitor the patient's condition and provide aggressive treatment to prevent further deterioration. This may include adjusting his medications, providing additional oxygen therapy, and performing further diagnostic tests to rule out other potential causes of his symptoms.

TEXT:
TITLE:

   56M with asthma, DM, HTN presenting with respiratory distress and
   pneumonia/ARDS from influenza A/H1N1.
   .
   # New Respiratory failure: Originally ARDS/sepsis combined w/ fluid
   overload and possible bacterial pneumonia. Pt had a trach placed.  Has
   been off sedating drips for 2 days and had been doing well on pressure
   support.  Patient experienced distress in setting of receiving 400ml of
   IVF after being NPO for greater than 24 hours.  Vent settings adjusted
   and patient sedated.  Repeated CXR which showed pulmonary edema and
   gave lasix.  Bed in reverse Trendelenberg.  Patient improved saturation
   (100%FiO2 and 12 of PEEP to 50% and 5 PEEP) but is still agitated,
   tachypneic, and tachycardic.   Patient could have VAP especially in
   setting of recent trach placement and fever spike this morning.
   - Hold Lasix for now, pursue infectious source and restart diuresis
   possibly in the future; does not clinically appear volume overloaded
   today
   - F/u cultures of blood, sputum, and urine, f/u mini-BAL
   - Continue antibiotics: vanc, cefipime, and cipro (all 3 started on
   [**12-23**]) for MRSA and double pseudomonas coverage
   - Nebulizer treatments and suctioning
   - Sedation: d/c Fentanyl and versed. Start methadone 5mg PO q8h.
   - Attempt trach-mask trial today
   - Wean down FiO2
   .
   #Fevers/leukocytosis: Febrile to 101.4 this morning.  Pan-cultured, but
   no clear source and Cx's negative this morning.  Had been spiking
   fevers recently despite clinical improvement.  Right IJ was pulled last
   night and tip will be cultured.  Currently off of antibiotics, and
   given lack of source we will not start any medications at this time.
   Has completed courses of Azithro, Peramivir, and continuing Vanc/Aztreo
   had been discussed. However, he had  received full courses of these ABx
   and it seemed reasonable to see how he did off of these; but now, given
   fever, worsening respiratory status, and lower BP, want to start
   empiric coverage.
   - Continue antibiotics for empiric coverage = vancomycin, cefepime,
   ciprofloxacin (started all 3 on [**12-23**])
   - Follow up all cultures, including catheter tip and mini-BAL
   .
   # Tachycardia: Previously appeared to have multifocal atrial
   tachycardia. Patient started previously on Lopressor; then held for
   tenuous clinical status. Tolerating HR.
   - monitor on telemetry
   .
   # Anemia: Did have a minor surgery yesterday but wouldn't think pt
   would lose a whole unit of blood.  Repeat Hcts have been stable.  Will
   continue to follow and transfuse if below 25 so that PEG can be placed.
   - q12 hour Hct
   -transfuse if below 25
   .
   # DM2: Was on insulin gtt until recently, but now switched to Glargine
   40U qhs and SSI. Has increasing SSI needs; now on [**Month/Year (2) **]
   - Re-calculate insulin requirements today
 increase glargine to 45U
   qhs.
   .
   #PEG placement: Dobhoff placed yesterday, and is now more stable
   clinically.  Surgery and GI have deferred placement of PEG to IR b/c of
   h/o volvulus, low albumin, and low Hcts.  IR so far has agreed to do
   procedure, but will wait until clinically improves.
   - Contact IR
   - [**Name2 (NI) 1851**] with Dobhoff for now
   # Critical illness myopathy:
   - F/u PT consult
   .
   Other stable issues:
    #Renal failure: Urine output and creatinine have improved.  Has muddy
   casts on urine sediment per renal, seems to have component of ATN.  Has
   really improved with treatment and improvement of ARDS.
   - Off of lasix gtt; consider Lasix later today pending I
s and O
   - Renal team has signed off
   .
   # Eye redness and discharge: Per nursing, patient had contact in his
   right eye which was only removed the other day as there was no record
   that patient wore contacts. Unable to find contact in left eye.  Seen
   by ophthalmology who mentioned that contact was intentionally there.
   Also suggested some changes to his eye-drops and outpatient follow-up.
   Patient already has outpatient appointment set up.
   - Prednisolone and tobramycin drops to R eye as prescribed.
   - Artificial tears ointment to both eyes
   .
   # Rash: Rash seems to be improving now that zosyn d/c
d.  No signs of
   DRESS.  Has some signs of folliculitis today
   - Chlorhexadine wash on arms and legs to help prevent infection of
   follicles
   - Continue to monitor, especially w/ starting cefepime.
   .
   #Abdominal distension: Seems to have poor motility with paralysis that
   leads to increasing bowel distention.  Will continue gentle tube feeds.
   Patient has had some loose stools today, checked C. diff to ensure that
   he is not infected given that he is on a large number of antibiotics
   and was negative X3.  Rectal tube placed which seems to be improving
   his distention.
   - Bowel regimen.
   -Continue rectal tube
   .
   # Hypothyroidism: Per most recent d/c summary, Synthroid at 50mcg daily
   or 25 IV.  Continued here.
   .
   #GERD: PPI
   .
   FEN: No IVF, replete electrolytes PRN, renal tube feeds. Consider PEG
   placement soon but not today (by IR; not by GI or surgery). NG tube in
   place.
   Prophylaxis: Subcutaneous heparin; pneumoboots, PPI and bowel regimen
   Access: 2 peripherals, A-line (might need to re-wire today), IJ Central
   line pulled. Place order for PICC to be placed tomorrow, for antibiotic
   delivery.
   Code:  Full Code as discussed with parents.
   Communication: Father and mother who are in to see him daily.
   Disposition: Pending improved respiratory status.

Summary:

The patient is a 56-year-old male with a history of asthma, diabetes, and hypertension who was admitted to the ICU with respiratory failure, low-grade fevers, and acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS) secondary to influenza A/H1N1 pneumonia. He has been treated with antibiotics, sedation, and mechanical ventilation. Recent events include a fever spike, which was pan-cultured, and a Dobhoff tube placement for enteral nutrition.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP): The patient's recent tracheostomy and prolonged mechanical ventilation make him at risk for VAP.
2. Respiratory failure: The patient's ARDS and pneumonia may lead to further respiratory decline, requiring continued mechanical ventilation and oxygen therapy.
3. Sepsis: The patient's fevers, leukocytosis, and positive blood cultures suggest the possibility of sepsis, which may worsen his respiratory status and increase the risk of multi-organ failure.
4. Renal failure: The patient's acute kidney injury may progress to chronic kidney disease, requiring ongoing management and potential dialysis.
5. Constipation: The patient's bowel regimen and rectal tube placement may lead to constipation, which can worsen his abdominal distension and increase the risk of bowel obstruction.
6. Hyperglycemia: The patient's diabetes and insulin therapy may lead to hyperglycemia, which can worsen his respiratory status and increase the risk of complications.
7. Critical illness myopathy: The patient's prolonged mechanical ventilation and sedation may lead to critical illness myopathy, which can worsen his respiratory status and increase the risk of prolonged ventilation.
8. Eye complications: The patient's recent contact lens use and ophthalmology consultation may lead to eye complications, such as conjunctivitis or keratitis.
9. Rash: The patient's recent antibiotic use and skin rash may indicate an allergic reaction or infection, which requires ongoing monitoring and management.
10. Abdominal distension: The patient's poor motility and bowel distension may worsen his respiratory status and increase the risk of bowel obstruction or perforation.

TEXT:

   56M with asthma, DM, HTN presenting with respiratory distress and
   pneumonia/ARDS from influenza A/H1N1.
   .
   # New Respiratory failure: Originally ARDS/sepsis combined w/ fluid
   overload and possible bacterial pneumonia. Pt had a trach placed.  Has
   been off sedating drips for 2 days and had been doing well on pressure
   support.  This morning he is tachypneic and alkalotic.  This does not
   change with decreasing pressure support.  We will tolerate this for
   now, and attempt to have more uniform sedation with long-acting
   methadone rather than bolusing fentanyl once an hour.
   - Start methadone 10mg TID
   - F/u cultures of blood, sputum, and urine, f/u mini-BAL
   - Continue antibiotics: vanc, cefipime, and cipro (all 3 started on
   [**12-23**]) for MRSA and double pseudomonas coverage
   - Nebulizer treatments and suctioning
   - Attempt trach-mask trial today
   - Wean down FiO2
   .
   #Fevers/leukocytosis: Fever curve and leukocytosis improved with
   antibiotics (on vanc, cipro and cefepime) and CV line removal. Had
   completed courses of Azithro, Peramivir, vanco and aztreonam for
   bacterial overgrowth of pneumonia.  We will continue all antibiotics
   for now and consider narrowing to single pseudomonal coverage if he
   remains afebrile.
   - Continue antibiotics for empiric coverage = vancomycin, cefepime,
   ciprofloxacin (started all 3 on [**12-23**])
   - Follow up all cultures, including catheter tip and mini-BAL
   .
   # DM2: Was on insulin gtt until recently, but now switched to Glargine
   40U qhs and SSI. Has increasing SSI needs; now on [**Month/Year (2) **]
   - Re-calculate insulin requirements today
 increase glargine to 45U
   qhs.
   .
   # Tachycardia: Previously appeared to have multifocal atrial
   tachycardia. Patient started previously on Lopressor; then held for
   tenuous clinical status. Today he is still tachycardic to the low 100s,
   but we will tolerate that for the time being.
   - monitor on telemetry
   .
   # Anemia: Hematocrits stable for several days now after trending down
   on admission.  Will continue to monitor daily.
   -transfuse if below 21
   .
   #PEG placement: Dobhoff placed yesterday, and is now more stable
   clinically.  Surgery and GI have deferred placement of PEG to IR b/c of
   h/o volvulus, low albumin, and low Hcts.  IR so far has agreed to do
   procedure, but will wait until clinically improves.
   - Contact IR
   - [**Name2 (NI) 1851**] with Dobhoff for now
   .
   # Critical illness myopathy:
   - F/u PT consult
   .
   Other stable issues:
    #Renal failure: Urine output and creatinine have improved.  Had
   component of ATN with muddy casts in urine.  Has really improved with
   treatment and improvement of ARDS.
   - Off of lasix gtt; consider Lasix later today pending I
s and O
   - Renal team has signed off
   .
   # Eye redness and discharge: Per nursing, patient had contact in his
   right eye which was only removed the other day as there was no record
   that patient wore contacts. Unable to find contact in left eye.  Seen
   by ophthalmology who mentioned that contact was intentionally there.
   Also suggested some changes to his eye-drops and outpatient follow-up.
   Patient already has outpatient appointment set up.
   - Prednisolone and tobramycin drops to R eye as prescribed.
   - Artificial tears ointment to both eyes
   .
   # Rash: Rash improved after zosyn d/c
d.  No signs of DRESS.  Did have
   some follicles which are improving.
   - Chlorhexadine wash on arms and legs to help prevent infection of
   follicles
   - Continue to monitor, especially w/ starting cefepime.
   .
   #Abdominal distension: Had poor motility with paralysis causing bowel
   distention.  Will continue gentle tube feeds. Patient has had some
   loose stools today, checked C. diff to ensure that he is not infected
   given that he is on a large number of antibiotics and was negative X3.
   Rectal tube placed which seems to be improving his distention.
   - Bowel regimen.
   - Continue rectal tube
   .
   # Hypothyroidism: Per most recent d/c summary, Synthroid at 50mcg daily
   or 25 IV.  Continued here.
   .
   #GERD: PPI
   .
   FEN: No IVF, replete electrolytes PRN, renal tube feeds. PEG to be
   placed by IR. Dobhoff in place for now.
   Prophylaxis: Subcutaneous heparin; pneumoboots, PPI and bowel regimen
   Access: 2 peripherals, A-line (might need to re-wire today). Placed
   order for PICC to be placed tomorrow, for antibiotic delivery.
   Code:  Full Code as discussed with parents.
   Communication: Father and mother who are in to see him daily.
   Disposition: Pending improved respiratory status.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 56-year-old male with a history of asthma, diabetes, and hypertension, who presented with respiratory distress and pneumonia/ARDS from influenza A/H1N1.

The patient's current condition is as follows:

* Respiratory: The patient is experiencing tachypnea and alkalosis, which is not responding to decreasing pressure support. He is being weaned down on FiO2 and will be attempted to be extubated today.
* Fever: The patient's fever curve has improved with antibiotics, and he is being continued on vancomycin, cefepime, and ciprofloxacin for empiric coverage.
* Renal: The patient's urine output and creatinine have improved, and he is no longer on lasix. The renal team has signed off, and the patient will be re-evaluated later today.
* Electrolytes: The patient's electrolytes are being monitored and replenished as needed.
* Hemodynamics: The patient's blood pressure is stable, and he is being monitored on telemetry.
* Neurological: The patient is experiencing tachycardia, which is being monitored and managed.
* Gastrointestinal: The patient has abdominal distension, which is being managed with gentle tube feeds and a rectal tube. He has had some loose stools and is being monitored for C. diff infection.
* Endocrine: The patient has hypothyroidism and is being managed with Synthroid.
* Skin: The patient has a rash, which has improved after discontinuing Zosyn and is being monitored for signs of DRESS.

Potential medical complications that may arise include:

* Respiratory failure: The patient's tachypnea and alkalosis may worsen, leading to respiratory failure.
* Sepsis: The patient's fever and leukocytosis may indicate sepsis, which could lead to organ dysfunction.
* Renal failure: The patient's urine output and creatinine may worsen, leading to renal failure.
* Electrolyte imbalances: The patient's electrolytes may become imbalanced, leading to cardiac arrhythmias and muscle weakness.
* Neurological complications: The patient's tachycardia and altered mental status may worsen, leading to neurological complications such as seizures or stroke.
* Gastrointestinal complications: The patient's abdominal distension and constipation may worsen, leading to gastrointestinal complications such as bowel obstruction or perforation.
* Endocrine complications: The patient's hypothyroidism may worsen, leading to hypothyroidism-related complications such as myxedema coma.

The patient's plan of care includes:

* Continuing antibiotics for empiric coverage
* Monitoring for signs of sepsis and organ dysfunction
* Re-evaluating the patient's respiratory status and considering extubation
* Monitoring the patient's electrolytes and replenishing as needed
* Managing the patient's gastrointestinal symptoms with gentle tube feeds and a rectal tube
* Monitoring the patient's neurological status and managing tachycardia
* Managing the patient's endocrine disorder with Synthroid
* Monitoring the patient's skin for signs of DRESS and managing the rash with chlorhexadine wash.

 AIRWAY, INABILITY TO PROTECT (RISK FOR ASPIRATION, ALTERED GAG,
   AIRWAY CLEARANCE, COUGH)
   56M with asthma, DM, HTN presenting with respiratory distress and
   pneumonia/ARDS from influenza A/H1N1.
   .
   # New Respiratory failure: Originally ARDS/sepsis combined w/ fluid
   overload and possible bacterial pneumonia. Pt had a trach placed.  Has
   been off sedating drips for 2 days and had been doing well on pressure
   support.  Patient experienced distress in setting of receiving 400ml of
   IVF after being NPO for greater than 24 hours.  Vent settings adjusted
   and patient sedated.  Repeated CXR which showed pulmonary edema and
   gave lasix.  Bed in reverse Trendelenberg.  Patient improved saturation
   (100%FiO2 and 12 of PEEP to 50% and 5 PEEP) but is still agitated,
   tachypneic, and tachycardic.   Patient could have VAP especially in
   setting of recent trach placement and fever spike this morning.
   - Hold Lasix for now, pursue infectious source and restart diuresis
   possibly in the future.
   - F/u cultures of blood, sputum, and urine
   - Restart antibiotics: vanc, cefipime, and cipro for MRSA and double
   pseudomonas coverage
   - Nebulizer treatments and suctioning
   - Daily CXR
   - Sedation: bolus sedation with fentanyl and midazolam.
   - mini-BAL
   .
   #Fevers/leukocytosis: Febrile to 101.4 this morning.  Pan-cultured, but
   no clear source and Cx's negative this morning.  Had been spiking
   fevers recently despite clinical improvement.  Right IJ was pulled last
   night and tip will be cultured.  Currently off of antibiotics, and
   given lack of source we will not start any medications at this time.
   Has completed courses of Azithro, Peramivir, and continuing Vanc/Aztreo
   had been discussed. However, he had  received full courses of these ABx
   and it seemed reasonable to see how he did off of these; but now, given
   fever, worsening respiratory status, and lower BP, want to start
   empiric coverage.
   - Start antibiotics for empiric coverage = start vancomycin, cefepime,
   ciprofloxacin
   - Mini-BAL
   - Follow up all cultures, including catheter tip
   .
   # Tachycardia: Previously appeared to have multifocal atrial
   tachycardia. Patient started previously on Lopressor; yesterday held
   for tenuous clinical status.
   - restart metoprolol
   .
   # Anemia: Did have a minor surgery yesterday but wouldn't think pt
   would lose a whole unit of blood.  Repeat Hcts have been stable.  Will
   continue to follow and transfuse if below 25 so that PEG can be placed.
   - q12 hour Hct
   -transfuse if below 25
   .
   # DM2: Was on insulin gtt until recently, but now switched to Glargine
   40U qhs and SSI. Has increasing SSI needs.
   - Will calculate insulin requirements once pt has taken a full day of
   nutrition either by PEG or by TF, in order to accurately calculate
   insulin requirements. Not today, as pt currently NPO for PEG today.
   SSI.
   .
   #PEG placement: Dobhoff placed yesterday, and is now more stable
   clinically.  Should be able to
   Surgery and GI have deferred placement of PEG to IR b/c of h/o
   volvulus, low albumin, and low Hcts.  IR so far has agreed to do
   procedure, but will wait until clinically improves.
   - Reschedule gastrostomy w/ IR when improves clinically.
   # Critical illness myopathy:
   - Consult PT today
   .
   Other stable issues:
    #Renal failure: Urine output and creatinine have improved.  Has muddy
   casts on urine sediment per renal, seems to have component of ATN.  Has
   really improved with treatment and improvement of ARDS.
   - Off of lasix gtt; consider Lasix later today pending I
s and O
   - Renal team has signed off
   .
   # Eye redness and discharge: Per nursing, patient had contact in his
   right eye which was only removed the other day as there was no record
   that patient wore contacts. Unable to find contact in left eye.  Seen
   by ophthalmology who mentioned that contact was intentionally there.
   Also suggested some changes to his eye-drops and outpatient follow-up.
   Patient already has outpatient appointment set up.
   - Prednisolone and tobramycin drops to R eye as prescribed.
   - Artificial tears ointment to both eyes
   .
   # Rash: Rash seems to be improving now that zosyn d/c
d.  No signs of
   DRESS.  Has some signs of folliculitis today
   - Chlorhexadine wash on arms and legs to help prevent infection of
   follicles
   - Continue to monitor, especially w/ starting cefepime.
   .
   #Abdominal distension: Seems to have poor motility with paralysis that
   leads to increasing bowel distention.  Will continue gentle tube feeds.
   Patient has had some loose stools today, checked C. diff to ensure that
   he is not infected given that he is on a large number of antibiotics
   and was negative X3.  Rectal tube placed which seems to be improving
   his distention.
   - Bowel regimen.
   -Continue rectal tube
   .
   # Hypothyroidism: Per most recent d/c summary, Synthroid at 50mcg daily
   or 25 IV.  Continued here.
   .
   #GERD: PPI
   .
   FEN: No IVF, replete electrolytes PRN, renal tube feeds. Consider PEG
   placement soon but not today (by IR; not by GI or surgery). NG tube
   placement today.
   Prophylaxis: Subcutaneous heparin; pneumoboots, PPI and bowel regimen
   Access: 2 peripherals, A-line (might need to re-wire today), IJ Central
   line pulled.
   Code:  Full Code as discussed with parents.
   Communication: Father and mother who are in to see him daily.
   Disposition: Pending improved respiratory status.

Summary:

The patient is a 56-year-old male with a history of asthma, diabetes, and hypertension who was admitted with respiratory failure and pneumonia due to influenza A/H1N1. He has been intubated and is receiving mechanical ventilation. He has experienced fevers, tachycardia, and tachypnea, and has been treated with antibiotics, sedatives, and diuretics. He has also had a tracheostomy tube placed and is receiving nutrition via a Dobhoff tube.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP): Given the patient's recent tracheostomy and fever spike, there is a risk of developing VAP.
2. Sepsis: The patient's fever and tachycardia may indicate a systemic inflammatory response, which could progress to sepsis.
3. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory status remains unstable, and there is a risk of further deterioration.
4. Acute kidney injury (AKI): The patient's creatinine levels are elevated, and there is a risk of further kidney damage.
5. Constipation: The patient's abdominal distension and poor motility may lead to constipation, which could worsen his respiratory status.
6. Hyperglycemia: The patient's glucose levels are elevated, and there is a risk of further hyperglycemia.
7. Hypothyroidism: The patient's thyroid function is abnormal, and there is a risk of further thyroid dysfunction.
8. Pneumonia: The patient's chest X-ray shows pulmonary edema, which may indicate pneumonia.
9. ARDS: The patient's respiratory failure and pulmonary edema may indicate acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS).
10. Sepsis-induced cardiac dysfunction: The patient's tachycardia and hypertension may indicate cardiac dysfunction, which could worsen his respiratory status.

Recommendations:

1. Continue to monitor the patient's respiratory status and adjust ventilator settings as needed.
2. Perform daily chest X-rays to monitor for signs of pneumonia or worsening respiratory failure.
3. Continue to administer antibiotics and antifungals as directed.
4. Monitor the patient's glucose levels and adjust insulin therapy as needed.
5. Continue to provide nutrition via the Dobhoff tube and monitor for signs of constipation or bowel obstruction.
6. Monitor the patient's thyroid function and adjust thyroid hormone replacement therapy as needed.
7. Continue to monitor the patient's renal function and adjust diuretic therapy as needed.
8. Consider performing a mini-BAL to investigate the source of the patient's fever and respiratory failure.
9. Consider performing a tracheostomy tube change to reduce the risk of VAP.
10. Continue to monitor the patient's cardiac status and adjust therapy as needed.

Summary:

The patient is a 56-year-old man with Down's syndrome, who has been admitted to the ICU with ARDS secondary to Influenza PNA. He has a tracheostomy in place and is receiving mechanical ventilation. His vital signs are stable, with a temperature curve trending downward, but he remains tachypneic. He has a history of respiratory failure, sepsis, and acute renal failure. He is currently receiving various medications, including antibiotics, sedatives, and analgesics.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Respiratory Complications:
	* Respiratory alkalosis due to mechanical ventilation and underlying ARDS.
	* Risk of ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP) and ventilator-induced lung injury.
2. Cardiovascular Complications:
	* Hypotension due to sepsis and acute renal failure.
	* Cardiac arrhythmias due to electrolyte imbalances and underlying cardiac disease.
3. Neurological Complications:
	* Risk of increased intracranial pressure (ICP) due to sepsis and ARDS.
	* Risk of seizures due to electrolyte imbalances and underlying neurological disease.
4. Gastrointestinal Complications:
	* Risk of gastrointestinal bleeding due to coagulopathy and underlying gastrointestinal disease.
	* Risk of constipation due to medication and underlying gastrointestinal disease.
5. Renal Complications:
	* Risk of acute kidney injury (AKI) due to sepsis and ARDS.
	* Risk of chronic kidney disease (CKD) due to underlying renal disease.
6. Infection Complications:
	* Risk of nosocomial infections due to prolonged hospitalization and underlying immunosuppression.
	* Risk of antibiotic-resistant infections due to overuse of antibiotics.

Given the patient's complex medical history and current condition, it is essential to continue close monitoring and management of his respiratory, cardiovascular, neurological, gastrointestinal, renal, and infectious complications to prevent further deterioration and improve his outcome.

   The tracheostomy tip is at the midline with its tip 3 cm above the
   carina.
   The Dobbhoff tube tip is in the prepyloric location distal stomach, no
   change
   in extensive parenchymal opacities in cardiomediastinal silhouette is
   demonstrated in the short-term interval, thus the potentially present
   volume
   overload did not significantly change since the prior study.
   Microbiology: All cultures NTD; some PMN in sputum
   Assessment and Plan
   56M with asthma, DM, HTN presenting with respiratory distress and
   pneumonia/ARDS from influenza A/H1N1.
   .
   # Respiratory failure: Originally ARDS/sepsis combined w/ fluid
   overload and possible bacterial pneumonia. Pt had a trach placed.  Has
   been off sedating drips for 2 days and had been doing well on pressure
   support.  This morning he is tachypneic and alkalotic.  This does not
   change with decreasing pressure support.  We will tolerate this for
   now, and attempt to have more uniform sedation with long-acting
   methadone rather than bolusing fentanyl once an hour.
   - Start methadone 10mg TID
   - F/u cultures of blood, sputum, and urine, f/u mini-BAL
   - Continue antibiotics: vanc, cefipime, and cipro (all 3 started on
   [**12-23**]) for MRSA and double pseudomonas coverage
   - Nebulizer treatments and suctioning
   - Attempt trach-mask trial today
   - Wean down FiO2
   - 2L diuresis
   .
   #Fevers/leukocytosis: Fever curve and leukocytosis improved with
   antibiotics (on vanc, cipro and cefepime) and CV line removal. Had
   completed courses of Azithro, Peramivir, vanco and aztreonam for
   bacterial overgrowth of pneumonia.  We will continue all antibiotics
   for now and consider narrowing to single pseudomonal coverage if he
   remains afebrile.
   - Continue antibiotics for empiric coverage = vancomycin, cefepime,
   ciprofloxacin (started all 3 on [**12-23**])
   - Follow up all cultures, including catheter tip and mini-BAL
   .
   # DM2: Was on insulin gtt until recently, but now switched to Glargine
   40U qhs and SSI. Has increasing SSI needs; now on tubefeeds
   - Re-calculate insulin requirements today
 increased glargine to 45U
   qhs.
   .
   # Tachycardia: Previously appeared to have multifocal atrial
   tachycardia. Patient started previously on Lopressor; then held for
   tenuous clinical status. Today he is still tachycardic to the 80-110's,
   but we will tolerate that for the time being.
   - monitor on telemetry
   .
   # Anemia: Hematocrits stable for several days now after trending down
   on admission.  Will continue to monitor daily.
   -transfuse if below 21
   .
   #PEG placement: Dobhoff placed yesterday, and is now more stable
   clinically.  Surgery and GI have deferred placement of PEG to IR b/c of
   h/o volvulus, low albumin, and low Hcts.  IR so far has agreed to do
   procedure today.
   - Nutrition consult for PEG feeds
   .
   # Critical illness myopathy:
   - F/u PT consult
   .
   Other stable issues:
    #Renal failure: Urine output and creatinine have improved.  Had
   component of ATN with muddy casts in urine.  Has really improved with
   treatment and improvement of ARDS.
   - Off of lasix gtt; consider Lasix later today pending I
s and O
   - Renal team has signed off
   .
   # Eye redness and discharge: Per nursing, patient had contact in his
   right eye which was only removed the other day as there was no record
   that patient wore contacts. Unable to find contact in left eye.  Seen
   by ophthalmology who mentioned that contact was intentionally there.
   Also suggested some changes to his eye-drops and outpatient follow-up.
   Patient already has outpatient appointment set up.
   - Prednisolone and tobramycin drops to R eye as prescribed.
   - Artificial tears ointment to both eyes
   .
   # Rash: Rash improved after zosyn d/c
d.  No signs of DRESS.  Did have
   some follicles which are improving.
   - Chlorhexadine wash on arms and legs to help prevent infection of
   follicles
   - Continue to monitor, especially w/ starting cefepime.
   .
   #Abdominal distension: Had poor motility with paralysis causing bowel
   distention.  Will continue gentle tube feeds. Patient has had some
   loose stools today, checked C. diff to ensure that he is not infected
   given that he is on a large number of antibiotics and was negative X3.
   Rectal tube placed which seems to be improving his distention.
   - Bowel regimen.
   - Continue rectal tube
   .
   # Hypothyroidism: Per most recent d/c summary, Synthroid at 50mcg daily
   or 25 IV.  Continued here.
   .
   #GERD: PPI
   .
   FEN: No IVF, replete electrolytes PRN, renal tube feeds. PEG to be
   placed by IR. Dobhoff in place for now.
   Prophylaxis: Subcutaneous heparin; pneumoboots, PPI and bowel regimen
   Access: 1 peripherals, A-line (might need to re-wire today). Placed
   order for PICC to be placed tomorrow, for antibiotic delivery.
   Code:  Full Code as discussed with parents.
   Communication: Father and mother who are in to see him daily.
   Disposition: Pending improved respiratory status.

Based on the progress note, the patient is a 56-year-old male with a history of asthma, diabetes, and hypertension, who presented with respiratory distress and pneumonia/ARDS due to influenza A/H1N1. The patient is currently intubated and on mechanical ventilation, with a tracheostomy in place.

The patient's vital signs are:

* Temperature: 37.4°C (99.4°F)
* Heart rate: 90 bpm
* Blood pressure: 117/64 mmHg
* Respiratory rate: 16 breaths per minute
* SpO2: 97%
* Hemoglobin: 7.4 g/dL
* White blood cell count: 14.9 K/uL

The patient's laboratory results show:

* Creatinine: 1.1 mg/dL
* Blood urea nitrogen: 24 mg/dL
* Electrolytes: Na 145 mEq/L, K 4.3 mEq/L, Cl 102 mEq/L, HCO3 24 mEq/L
* Glucose: 116 mg/dL
* Albumin: 2.7 g/dL
* Calcium: 7.5 mg/dL
* Magnesium: 1.7 mg/dL
* Phosphorus: 3.4 mg/dL

The patient's imaging studies show:

* Chest X-ray: The tracheostomy tip is at the midline with its tip 3 cm above the carina. There are no changes in extensive parenchymal opacities in the cardiomediastinal silhouette.

The patient's medical issues include:

* Respiratory failure: The patient is on mechanical ventilation and has a tracheostomy in place. He is tachypneic and alkalotic, but is tolerating this for now.
* Fevers/leukocytosis: The patient's fever curve and leukocytosis improved with antibiotics, but he is still receiving empiric coverage for MRSA and pseudomonas.
* DM2: The patient is on insulin glargine 40U qhs and sliding scale insulin. He is having increasing sliding scale insulin needs and is now on tube feeds.
* Tachycardia: The patient is still tachycardic, but is being monitored on telemetry.
* Anemia: The patient's hematocrits are stable, but he may require transfusion if his hematocrit falls below 21.
* PEG placement: The patient's Dobhoff tube is in place, and he is scheduled to have a PEG placed today.
* Critical illness myopathy: The patient is being followed by a physical therapist.
* Renal failure: The patient's urine output and creatinine have improved, but he may require Lasix later today pending further evaluation.
* Eye redness and discharge: The patient has eye redness and discharge, which is being treated with eye drops and ointment.
* Rash: The patient's rash has improved, but he is still at risk for infection.
* Abdominal distension: The patient has abdominal distension due to poor motility, which is being treated with gentle tube feeds and a rectal tube.
* Hypothyroidism: The patient is being treated with Synthroid 50mcg daily or 25 IV.
* GERD: The patient is being treated with a proton pump inhibitor.

The patient's plan of care includes:

* Continue antibiotics for empiric coverage
* Monitor the patient's respiratory status and adjust his ventilator settings as needed
* Continue gentle tube feeds and monitor the patient's abdominal distension
* Place a PEG today
* Monitor the patient's electrolytes and adjust his fluids as needed
* Continue to monitor the patient's temperature and leukocytosis
* Continue to treat the patient's eye redness and discharge
* Continue to monitor the patient's rash and prevent infection
* Continue to treat the patient's hypothyroidism
* Continue to treat the patient's GERD

Potential medical complications that can arise include:

* Respiratory failure: The patient may experience further respiratory distress or failure, which could lead to respiratory arrest or death.
* Infection: The patient is at risk for infection due to his immunocompromised state and the presence of multiple tubes and lines.
* Sepsis: The patient may develop sepsis due to his underlying infections and the presence of multiple antibiotics.
* Renal failure: The patient's renal function may decline further, leading to renal failure or death.
* Gastrointestinal bleeding: The patient may experience gastrointestinal bleeding due to his underlying gastrointestinal disease and the presence of multiple tubes and lines.
* Eye complications: The patient may experience further eye complications, such as corneal ulcers or vision loss, due to his underlying eye disease and the presence of multiple eye tubes and drops.
* Skin complications: The patient may experience further skin complications, such as skin breakdown or infection, due to his underlying skin disease and the presence of multiple tubes and lines.

Overall, the patient is at high risk for multiple medical complications, and close monitoring and management are necessary to prevent or treat these complications.

 increased glargine to 45U

d.  No signs of DRESS.  Did have

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 56-year-old male with a history of asthma, diabetes, and hypertension who presented with respiratory distress and pneumonia/ARDS due to influenza A/H1N1.

The patient has been in the ICU for an unknown duration and has been receiving various treatments, including antibiotics, sedatives, and respiratory support.

The note highlights several concerns and issues:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient is tachypneic and alkalotic, which is not improving with decreasing pressure support. The plan is to tolerate this for now and attempt to have more uniform sedation with long-acting methadone.
2. Fevers/leukocytosis: The patient's fever curve and leukocytosis improved with antibiotics and CV line removal. However, the patient is still receiving multiple antibiotics, and the plan is to continue them for now and consider narrowing to single pseudomonal coverage if the patient remains afebrile.
3. DM2: The patient is receiving insulin therapy, and his glucose levels are being monitored. The plan is to re-calculate insulin requirements and adjust as needed.
4. Tachycardia: The patient is still tachycardic, but the plan is to tolerate this for the time being.
5. Anemia: The patient's hematocrits are stable, and the plan is to continue monitoring and transfuse if necessary.
6. PEG placement: The patient's Dobhoff tube is in place, and the plan is to have the IR place a PEG tube today.
7. Critical illness myopathy: The patient is at risk for this condition, and the plan is to follow up with a PT consult.
8. Renal failure: The patient's urine output and creatinine have improved, and the plan is to continue monitoring and adjust treatment as needed.
9. Eye redness and discharge: The patient has a rash in his right eye and is being treated with topical antibiotics and artificial tears.
10. Rash: The patient's rash has improved, and the plan is to continue monitoring and treat with chlorhexadine wash and topical antibiotics.
11. Abdominal distension: The patient has poor motility and is at risk for bowel obstruction. The plan is to continue gentle tube feeds and monitor for signs of distention.
12. Hypothyroidism: The patient is receiving thyroid replacement therapy, and the plan is to continue this.
13. GERD: The patient is receiving PPI therapy, and the plan is to continue this.

The patient's vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 37.4°C, heart rate of 90 bpm, and blood pressure of 117/64 mmHg. His respiratory rate is 16 breaths per minute, and his SpO2 is 97%.

The patient's laboratory results show:

* White blood cell count: 14.9 x 10^9/L
* Hematocrit: 26.4%
* Platelet count: 955 x 10^9/L
* Creatinine: 1.1 mg/dL
* Blood urea nitrogen: 24 mg/dL
* Glucose: 116 mg/dL
* Albumin: 2.7 g/dL
* Calcium: 7.5 mg/dL
* Magnesium: 1.7 mg/dL
* Phosphorus: 3.4 mg/dL

The patient's imaging studies show:

* CXR: The tracheostomy tip is at the midline, and the Dobbhoff tube tip is in the prepyloric location distal to the stomach.
* Mini-BAL: The patient has a positive culture for MRSA and double pseudomonas coverage.

The patient's medical team is concerned about the patient's respiratory failure, fevers/leukocytosis, and the potential for critical illness myopathy. They are also monitoring the patient's nutritional status, glucose levels, and electrolyte balance.

The patient's code status is full code, and his disposition is pending improved respiratory status.

   The tracheostomy tip is at the midline with its tip 3 cm above the
   carina.
   The Dobbhoff tube tip is in the prepyloric location distal stomach, no
   change
   in extensive parenchymal opacities in cardiomediastinal silhouette is
   demonstrated in the short-term interval, thus the potentially present
   volume

   Microbiology: All cultures NTD; some PMN in sputum
   Assessment and Plan
   56M with asthma, DM, HTN presenting with respiratory distress and
   pneumonia/ARDS from influenza A/H1N1.
   .
   # Respiratory failure: Originally ARDS/sepsis combined w/ fluid
   overload and possible bacterial pneumonia. Pt had a trach placed.  Has
   been off sedating drips for 2 days and had been doing well on pressure
   support.  This morning he is tachypneic and alkalotic.  This does not
   change with decreasing pressure support.  We will tolerate this for
   now, and attempt to have more uniform sedation with long-acting
   methadone rather than bolusing fentanyl once an hour.
   - Start methadone 10mg TID
   - F/u cultures of blood, sputum, and urine, f/u mini-BAL
   - Continue antibiotics: vanc, cefipime, and cipro (all 3 started on
   [**12-23**]) for MRSA and double pseudomonas coverage
   - Nebulizer treatments and suctioning
   - Attempt trach-mask trial today
   - Wean down FiO2
   .
   #Fevers/leukocytosis: Fever curve and leukocytosis improved with
   antibiotics (on vanc, cipro and cefepime) and CV line removal. Had
   completed courses of Azithro, Peramivir, vanco and aztreonam for
   bacterial overgrowth of pneumonia.  We will continue all antibiotics
   for now and consider narrowing to single pseudomonal coverage if he
   remains afebrile.
   - Continue antibiotics for empiric coverage = vancomycin, cefepime,
   ciprofloxacin (started all 3 on [**12-23**])
   - Follow up all cultures, including catheter tip and mini-BAL
   .
   # DM2: Was on insulin gtt until recently, but now switched to Glargine
   40U qhs and SSI. Has increasing SSI needs; now on tubefeeds
   - Re-calculate insulin requirements today
 increased glargine to 45U
   qhs.
   .
   # Tachycardia: Previously appeared to have multifocal atrial
   tachycardia. Patient started previously on Lopressor; then held for
   tenuous clinical status. Today he is still tachycardic to the 80-110's,
   but we will tolerate that for the time being.
   - monitor on telemetry
   .
   # Anemia: Hematocrits stable for several days now after trending down
   on admission.  Will continue to monitor daily.
   -transfuse if below 21
   .
   #PEG placement: Dobhoff placed yesterday, and is now more stable
   clinically.  Surgery and GI have deferred placement of PEG to IR b/c of
   h/o volvulus, low albumin, and low Hcts.  IR so far has agreed to do
   procedure today.
   - Contact IR for scheduling
   - Nutrition consult for PEG feeds
   .
   # Critical illness myopathy:
   - F/u PT consult
   .
   Other stable issues:
    #Renal failure: Urine output and creatinine have improved.  Had
   component of ATN with muddy casts in urine.  Has really improved with
   treatment and improvement of ARDS.
   - Off of lasix gtt; consider Lasix later today pending I
s and O
   - Renal team has signed off
   .
   # Eye redness and discharge: Per nursing, patient had contact in his
   right eye which was only removed the other day as there was no record
   that patient wore contacts. Unable to find contact in left eye.  Seen
   by ophthalmology who mentioned that contact was intentionally there.
   Also suggested some changes to his eye-drops and outpatient follow-up.
   Patient already has outpatient appointment set up.
   - Prednisolone and tobramycin drops to R eye as prescribed.
   - Artificial tears ointment to both eyes
   .
   # Rash: Rash improved after zosyn d/c
d.  No signs of DRESS.  Did have
   some follicles which are improving.
   - Chlorhexadine wash on arms and legs to help prevent infection of
   follicles
   - Continue to monitor, especially w/ starting cefepime.
   .
   #Abdominal distension: Had poor motility with paralysis causing bowel
   distention.  Will continue gentle tube feeds. Patient has had some
   loose stools today, checked C. diff to ensure that he is not infected
   given that he is on a large number of antibiotics and was negative X3.
   Rectal tube placed which seems to be improving his distention.
   - Bowel regimen.
   - Continue rectal tube
   .
   # Hypothyroidism: Per most recent d/c summary, Synthroid at 50mcg daily
   or 25 IV.  Continued here.
   .
   #GERD: PPI
   .
   FEN: No IVF, replete electrolytes PRN, renal tube feeds. PEG to be
   placed by IR. Dobhoff in place for now.
   Prophylaxis: Subcutaneous heparin; pneumoboots, PPI and bowel regimen
   Access: 2 peripherals, A-line (might need to re-wire today). Placed
   order for PICC to be placed tomorrow, for antibiotic delivery.
   Code:  Full Code as discussed with parents.
   Communication: Father and mother who are in to see him daily.
   Disposition: Pending improved respiratory status.
   ICU Care
   Nutrition:

Summary:

The patient is a 56-year-old male with a history of asthma, diabetes mellitus, and hypertension, admitted to the ICU with respiratory distress and pneumonia/ARDS due to influenza A/H1N1. He has been intubated and is receiving mechanical ventilation with a tracheostomy tube in place. The patient has been on sedating drips, but was weaned off two days ago. He is currently tachypneic and alkalotic, with a respiratory rate of 16 breaths per minute and a partial pressure of oxygen (PaO2) of 97%.

The patient has been diagnosed with ARDS, sepsis, and fluid overload, and has been treated with antibiotics, including vancomycin, cefepime, and ciprofloxacin. He has also been treated with corticosteroids and has had a tracheostomy tube placed. The patient's hemodynamic status is stable, with a mean arterial pressure of 117 mmHg and a heart rate of 90 beats per minute.

The patient's laboratory results show an elevated white blood cell count, with a peak of 14.9 x 10^9/L, and an elevated creatinine level, with a peak of 1.1 mg/dL. His liver function tests are abnormal, with elevated levels of alanine aminotransferase (ALT) and aspartate aminotransferase (AST). His glucose level is elevated, with a peak of 225 mg/dL.

Potential medical complications:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory status is unstable, with a tachypneic and alkalotic response to decreasing pressure support. He may require further treatment with sedatives and analgesics to manage his respiratory distress.
2. Sepsis: The patient has been diagnosed with sepsis and is receiving antibiotics. He may require further treatment with antibiotics and may need to be transferred to a medical ICU for further management.
3. Fluid overload: The patient has been diagnosed with fluid overload and is receiving diuretics. He may require further treatment with diuretics and may need to be transferred to a medical ICU for further management.
4. ARDS: The patient has been diagnosed with ARDS and is receiving mechanical ventilation. He may require further treatment with corticosteroids and may need to be transferred to a medical ICU for further management.
5. Pneumonia: The patient has been diagnosed with pneumonia and is receiving antibiotics. He may require further treatment with antibiotics and may need to be transferred to a medical ICU for further management.
6. Diabetes mellitus: The patient has been diagnosed with diabetes mellitus and is receiving insulin therapy. He may require further treatment with insulin and may need to be transferred to a medical ICU for further management.
7. Hypothyroidism: The patient has been diagnosed with hypothyroidism and is receiving levothyroxine therapy. He may require further treatment with levothyroxine and may need to be transferred to a medical ICU for further management.
8. GERD: The patient has been diagnosed with GERD and is receiving proton pump inhibitor therapy. He may require further treatment with proton pump inhibitors and may need to be transferred to a medical ICU for further management.
9. Critical illness myopathy: The patient has been diagnosed with critical illness myopathy and is receiving physical therapy. He may require further treatment with physical therapy and may need to be transferred to a medical ICU for further management.
10. Eye redness and discharge: The patient has been diagnosed with eye redness and discharge and is receiving treatment with artificial tears and antibiotic ointment. He may require further treatment with antibiotics and may need to be transferred to an ophthalmology ICU for further management.
11. Rash: The patient has been diagnosed with a rash and is receiving treatment with chlorhexidine wash and antibiotic ointment. He may require further treatment with antibiotics and may need to be transferred to a dermatology ICU for further management.
12. Abdominal distension: The patient has been diagnosed with abdominal distension and is receiving treatment with gentle tube feeds and rectal tube. He may require further treatment with bowel regimen and may need to be transferred to a gastroenterology ICU for further management.

Overall, the patient's condition is unstable and requires close monitoring and management in the ICU.

The patient is a 56-year-old man with Down's syndrome who was admitted with influenza PNA and ARDS. He is currently receiving respiratory support with a tracheostomy tube and mechanical ventilation. His vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 37.6°C, heart rate of 87 bpm, and blood pressure of 109/59 mmHg. His respiratory rate is 13 breaths per minute, and his oxygen saturation is 99%.

The patient's physical examination reveals no acute distress, with normal cardiovascular and abdominal examinations. His extremities show 1+ edema in both lower limbs, and his skin is warm. Neurologically, he is attentive, follows simple commands, and responds to verbal stimuli.

Laboratory results show mild anemia, elevated white blood cell count, and acute kidney injury. His liver enzymes are mildly elevated, and his electrolytes are within normal limits.

The patient's medical conditions include respiratory failure, pulmonary edema, fever, tachycardia, rash, acute renal failure, constipation, hyperglycemia, acute respiratory distress syndrome, sepsis without organ dysfunction, pneumonia, and airway compromise.

Potential medical complications that can arise include:

1. Respiratory failure: Continued weaning of mechanical ventilation may be necessary to prevent further respiratory compromise.
2. Pneumonia: The patient's respiratory support and antibiotics may need to be adjusted to prevent further bacterial growth.
3. Acute kidney injury: Close monitoring of the patient's kidney function and fluid status is necessary to prevent further kidney damage.
4. Hyperglycemia: The patient's blood glucose levels need to be closely monitored and adjusted to prevent further hyperglycemia.
5. Constipation: The patient's bowel habits need to be monitored to prevent further constipation and potential complications.
6. Sepsis: The patient's sepsis needs to be closely monitored and managed to prevent further organ dysfunction.
7. Pneumonia: The patient's pneumonia needs to be closely monitored and managed to prevent further complications.
8. Airway compromise: The patient's airway needs to be closely monitored to prevent further compromise and potential complications.

In summary, the patient is critically ill and requires close monitoring and management to prevent further complications.

   56M with asthma, DM, HTN presenting with respiratory distress and
   pneumonia/ARDS from influenza A/H1N1.
   # Respiratory failure: Originally ARDS/sepsis combined w/ fluid
   overload and possible bacterial pneumonia. Pt had a trach placed.  Has
   been off sedating drips for 3 days and had been doing well on pressure
   support.  This morning he continues to be respiratorily alkalotic. Has
   started on Methadone to try and decrease his tachypnea, instead of
   bolusing sedatives.
   - Continue methadone 10mg TID to address tachypnea
   - F/u ABG this afternoon
   - Trach mask trial later today
   - F/u cultures of blood, sputum, and urine, f/u mini-BAL
   - Continue antibiotics: vanc, cefipime, and cipro (all 3 started on
   [**12-23**] --> today is day 4) for MRSA and double pseudomonas coverage
   - Nebulizer treatments and suctioning
   - Wean down FiO2
   - 2L diuresis again today given worsening effusions
   #Fevers/leukocytosis: Fever curve and leukocytosis improved with
   antibiotics (on vanc, cipro and cefepime) and CV line removal. Had
   completed courses of Azithro, Peramivir, vanco and aztreonam for
   bacterial overgrowth of pneumonia.  We will continue all antibiotics
   for now and consider narrowing to single pseudomonal coverage if he
   remains afebrile.
   - Continue antibiotics for empiric coverage = vancomycin, cefepime,
   ciprofloxacin (started all 3 on [**12-23**])
   - Follow up all cultures, including catheter tip and mini-BAL
   # DM2: Was on insulin gtt until recently, but now switched to Glargine
   40U qhs and SSI. Has increasing SSI needs; now on tubefeeds
   - Re-calculate insulin requirements today
 increased glargine to 45U
   qhs.
   - Watch BS's through the day and increase accordingly
   # Tachycardia: Previously appeared to have multifocal atrial
   tachycardia. Patient started previously on Lopressor; then held for
   tenuous clinical status. Today he is still tachycardic to the 80-110's,
   but we will tolerate that for the time being.
   - monitor on telemetry
   # Anemia: Hematocrits stable for several days now after trending down
   on admission.  Will continue to monitor daily.
   -transfuse if below 21
   #PEG placement: Currently getting Novasource renal
   # Critical illness myopathy:
   - F/u PT consult
   Other stable issues:
    #Renal failure: Urine output and creatinine have improved.  Had
   component of ATN with muddy casts in urine.  Has really improved with
   treatment and improvement of ARDS.
   - Off of lasix gtt; consider Lasix later today pending I
s and O
   - Renal team has signed off
   # Eye redness and discharge: Per nursing, patient had contact in his
   right eye which was only removed the other day as there was no record
   that patient wore contacts. Unable to find contact in left eye.  Seen
   by ophthalmology who mentioned that contact was intentionally there.
   Also suggested some changes to his eye-drops and outpatient follow-up.
   Patient already has outpatient appointment set up.
   - Prednisolone and tobramycin drops to R eye as prescribed.
   - Artificial tears ointment to both eyes
   # Rash: Rash improved after zosyn d/c
d.  No signs of DRESS.  Did have
   some follicles which are improving.
   - Chlorhexadine wash on arms and legs to help prevent infection of
   follicles
   - Continue to monitor, especially w/ starting cefepime.
   #Abdominal distension: Had poor motility with paralysis causing bowel
   distention.  Will continue gentle tube feeds. Patient has had some
   loose stools today, checked C. diff to ensure that he is not infected
   given that he is on a large number of antibiotics and was negative X3.
   Rectal tube placed which seems to be improving his distention.
   - Bowel regimen.
   - Continue rectal tube
   # Hypothyroidism: Per most recent d/c summary, Synthroid at 50mcg daily
   or 25 IV.  Continued here.
   #GERD: PPI
   FEN: No IVF, replete electrolytes PRN, renal tube feeds.
   Prophylaxis: Subcutaneous heparin; pneumoboots, PPI and bowel regimen
   Access: 1 peripherals, A-line (might need to re-wire today). Placed
   order for PICC to be placed tomorrow, for antibiotic delivery.
   Code:  Full Code as discussed with parents.
   Communication: Father and mother who are in to see him daily.
   Disposition: Pending improved respiratory status.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 56-year-old male with a complex medical history, including asthma, diabetes, and hypertension, who presented with respiratory distress and pneumonia/acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS) from influenza A/H1N1.

The patient has undergone various interventions, including tracheostomy placement, mechanical ventilation, and antibiotic therapy. The patient's current condition is characterized by:

1. Respiratory alkalosis: The patient's pH is 7.49, indicating respiratory alkalosis.
2. Pneumonia/ARDS: The patient has worsening effusions bilaterally on chest X-ray.
3. Sepsis: The patient has been treated with antibiotics, and cultures are pending.
4. Acute kidney injury (AKI): The patient's creatinine has improved, but the patient remains at risk for AKI.
5. Constipation: The patient has been experiencing constipation, which may be related to his underlying medical conditions or medications.
6. Hyperglycemia: The patient's blood glucose levels have been elevated, and he requires insulin therapy.
7. Tachycardia: The patient's heart rate has been elevated, and he is being monitored on telemetry.

The patient's plan of care includes:

1. Continue methadone to address tachypnea.
2. F/u ABG this afternoon.
3. Trach mask trial later today.
4. Continue antibiotics for empiric coverage.
5. F/u cultures of blood, sputum, and urine.
6. Wean down FiO2.
7. 2L diuresis again today given worsening effusions.
8. Re-calculate insulin requirements today.
9. Monitor blood sugars through the day and increase accordingly.
10. F/u PT consult.

Potential medical complications that can arise include:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory status may continue to deteriorate, requiring further interventions.
2. Sepsis: The patient's sepsis may worsen, leading to organ dysfunction.
3. AKI: The patient's kidney function may continue to decline, requiring dialysis.
4. Constipation: The patient's constipation may worsen, leading to bowel obstruction or perforation.
5. Hyperglycemia: The patient's hyperglycemia may lead to diabetic ketoacidosis or hyperosmolar hyperglycemic nonketotic syndrome.
6. Tachycardia: The patient's tachycardia may lead to cardiac arrhythmias or cardiac failure.

It is essential to closely monitor the patient's condition and adjust his plan of care accordingly to prevent these potential complications and improve his overall outcome.

   been off sedating drips for several days and had been doing well on
   pressure support.  Has started on Methadone to try and decrease his
   tachypnea, instead of bolusing sedatives, and also as a wean from the
   sedation that he has been on for the past several weeks.
   - Continue methadone 10mg TID to address tachypnea
   - F/u ABG this afternoon
   - Trach mask trial later today
   - F/u cultures of blood, sputum, and urine, f/u mini-BAL

   - Nebulizer treatments and suctioning
   - Wean down FiO2

   antibiotics (on vanc, cipro and cefepime) and CV line removal. Had
   completed courses of Azithro, Peramivir, vanco and aztreonam for
   bacterial overgrowth of pneumonia, was then restarted on
   Vanc/Cefepime/Cipro.
   - Will d/c ABx as above as we have no clear source that we are
   treating.
   - Follow up all cultures, including catheter tip and mini-BAL
   # DM2: Was on insulin gtt until recently, but now switched to Glargine
   40U qhs and SSI. Has increasing SSI needs; now on tubefeeds
   - Glargine has been recently increased to 45 qhs
   - Watch BS's through the day and increase accordingly

   treatment and improvement of ARDS.

   right eye which was only removed the other day as there was no record
   that patient wore contacts. Unable to find contact in left eye.  Seen
   by ophthalmology who mentioned that contact was intentionally there.

d.  No signs of DRESS.  Did have

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 56-year-old male with a history of asthma, diabetes mellitus (DM), and hypertension, who presented with respiratory distress and pneumonia/acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS) from influenza A/H1N1.

The patient has undergone several interventions, including tracheostomy placement, mechanical ventilation, and antibiotics. He has been weaned off sedating drips and is now on methadone 10mg TID to address tachypnea.

The patient's current condition is as follows:

* Respiratory status: The patient is still requiring mechanical ventilation and has a respiratory rate of 10 breaths per minute. His oxygen saturation is 100% on 50% FiO2.
* Cardiovascular status: The patient's heart rate is 86 beats per minute, and his blood pressure is 94/50 mmHg.
* Renal status: The patient's urine output has improved, and his creatinine level is within baseline.
* Hematological status: The patient's hematocrit is stable, and he has been transfused with packed red blood cells.
* Gastrointestinal status: The patient has been switched to Glargine insulin and is receiving tube feeds.
* Endocrine status: The patient has hypothyroidism and is receiving Synthroid 50mcg daily or 25 IV.
* Skin status: The patient has a rash that has improved after discontinuing Zosyn, and he is receiving chlorhexadine wash to prevent infection.

Potential medical complications that can arise from the patient's current condition include:

* Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory status is still unstable, and he may require further interventions to improve his oxygenation and ventilation.
* Sepsis: The patient has a history of sepsis, and he may be at risk for developing sepsis again, particularly if his respiratory status deteriorates.
* Renal failure: The patient's urine output has improved, but he may still be at risk for developing acute kidney injury or chronic kidney disease.
* Gastrointestinal complications: The patient is receiving tube feeds, and he may be at risk for developing gastrointestinal complications such as nausea, vomiting, or diarrhea.
* Endocrine complications: The patient has hypothyroidism, and he may be at risk for developing endocrine complications such as hypothyroidism or hyperthyroidism.
* Skin complications: The patient has a rash that has improved, but he may still be at risk for developing skin complications such as infections or allergic reactions.

Based on the patient's current condition and potential complications, the following plan of care is recommended:

* Continue to monitor the patient's respiratory status and adjust his mechanical ventilation settings as needed.
* Continue to provide antibiotics and antiviral medications as prescribed.
* Monitor the patient's urine output and creatinine level to assess his renal function.
* Continue to provide tube feeds and monitor the patient's nutritional status.
* Monitor the patient's endocrine status and adjust his thyroid medication as needed.
* Monitor the patient's skin status and provide chlorhexadine wash as prescribed.
* Continue to provide prophylactic antibiotics and antiviral medications as prescribed.
* Consider placing a PICC line to facilitate antibiotic delivery.
* Continue to monitor the patient's code status and disposition.
